title: Iodine Deficiency and Fertility (Episode 610)
main_text:
Your Podcast Host:
Lisa Hendrickson-Jack is a certified fertility awareness educator and holistic reproductive health practitioner with over 20 years of experience teaching fertility awareness and menstrual cycle literacy. She is the author (and co-author) of two widely referenced resources in the field of fertility awareness and menstrual health, The Fifth Vital Sign and Real Food for Fertility, and the host of the long-running Fertility Friday Podcast. Lisa’s main focus is her Fertility Awareness Mastery Mentorship (FAMM) Certification — an evidence-based fertility awareness certification program for women’s health professionals.
Audio Player
00:00
00:00
Use Up/Down Arrow keys to increase or decrease volume.
Podcast: Play in new window | Download | Embed
Subscribe: Apple Podcasts | RSS
Episode Summary: How Low Iodine Levels May Affect Time to Pregnancy
In this solo episode, Lisa reviews a peer-reviewed study exploring the connection between iodine deficiency and time to conception. The research followed over 500 couples trying to conceive and found that women with low urinary iodine levels were significantly less likely to conceive per cycle. Lisa unpacks the study design, outcomes, and implications, highlighting how iodine status may influence reproductive function. She also discusses iodine’s role beyond thyroid health, including its concentration in breast and ovarian tissue. With nearly half of the participants showing some level of deficiency, the study raises important questions about iodine’s relevance for women of reproductive age. This episode offers a closer look at one of the most debated nutrients in fertility and hormone health.
Key Topics Covered: Understanding Iodine’s Role in Fertility
The featured research study examining iodine deficiency and delayed conception
How urinary iodine concentrations were used to assess iodine status in women trying to conceive
Study findings linking low iodine levels to reduced chances of conception per cycle
Prevalence of iodine deficiency among women of reproductive age in population studies
Iodine’s role beyond thyroid hormone production, including broader hormonal function
The concentration of iodine in breast and ovarian tissue and its relevance to reproductive health
Why iodine remains one of the most controversial nutrients in women’s health discussions
Listener Takeaways for Practitioners Supporting Clients with Preconception Care
Iodine deficiency was associated with a longer time to pregnancy in a large cohort of couples actively trying to conceive.
The study measured iodine status using urinary iodine concentrations, which are commonly used in population-level research.
Women with low iodine levels were found to be significantly less likely to conceive per menstrual cycle compared to those with sufficient levels.
A substantial proportion of women of reproductive age in the study showed mild to severe iodine deficiency, reflecting broader population trends.
Iodine plays roles beyond thyroid hormone production, including involvement in overall hormone function and reproductive tissues.
The episode highlights why iodine remains a debated nutrient in women’s health, particularly in the context of fertility and thyroid-related discussions.

Timestamped Breakdown: Iodine Research and Reproductive Health
Why is iodine such a controversial nutrient in fertility care? (0:57–1:33)
Lisa introduces iodine as one of the most debated nutrients in women’s health and explains why differing practitioner opinions often center on its relationship with thyroid function.
What does the featured study on iodine and conception investigate? (1:33–4:30)
The episode centers on a population-based study examining how low urinary iodine concentrations relate to time to pregnancy in women trying to conceive.
How was iodine status measured and fertility tracked in the study? (4:30–7:15)
Lisa explains the study design, including cycle tracking instructions, use of fertility monitors, and urinary iodine testing to assess iodine sufficiency.
What did the study find about iodine deficiency and time to pregnancy? (7:15–9:45)
The results showed that women with iodine deficiency were significantly less likely to conceive per cycle and experienced longer times to pregnancy.
How common is iodine deficiency among women of reproductive age? (9:45–12:10)
Lisa reviews population data from the study, noting that nearly half of the participants showed some level of iodine deficiency, aligning with broader research trends.
Why does iodine matter beyond thyroid health? (12:10–15:45)
The discussion expands to iodine’s role in hormone production, breast and ovarian tissue, and its potential connection to cystic conditions.
What broader insights does this research offer for fertility education? (15:45–20:49)
Lisa reflects on the importance of viewing iodine as one part of overall nutrient sufficiency and highlights the need for continued research and practitioner education.
TRANSCRIPT
+

Educational Notice
The information shared in this podcast episode is intended for educational and informational purposes only. The Fertility Friday Podcast does not provide medical advice, diagnosis, or treatment, and the content is not a substitute for personalized care from a licensed healthcare professional.
Topics related to fertility awareness, menstrual cycle health, nutrition, exercise, and lifestyle factors are discussed at a general educational level. Individual health histories and needs vary, so what applies to one person may not apply to another.
If you have questions about symptoms, medications, fertility, or your personal health situation, please consult a qualified healthcare provider. Any guest opinions are their own and do not necessarily reflect the views of Fertility Friday or its host.

title: The Problem With Current Sperm Guidelines | FAMM Research Series
main_text:
The Problem With Current Sperm Guidelines
Houston we have a problem! The current sperm guidelines don’t provide us with optimal values for natural conception. Instead, they provide a low bar below which further medical support is most likely required. Tune in for the full story!
Timestamps
00:00 – Chart interpretation overwhelm & practitioner frustration
01:00 – Why sperm guidelines matter (and where they came from)
04:30 – WHO reference values & how “normal” was defined
07:45 – Percentiles explained & the lower 5th percentile problem
10:20 – Normal vs optimal fertility: a critical distinction
13:35 – Optimal sperm parameters vs WHO guidelines
16:20 – Declining sperm counts: past vs present
18:55 – The missing suboptimal range & longer time to pregnancy
22:15 – Why male fertility deserves more clinical attention
27:45 – Bottom line: what these guidelines were never meant to do
Key Takeaways
WHO sperm reference ranges are based on the lowest 5th percentile of men who conceived within a year—not on optimal fertility.
Being told a semen analysis is “normal” can create false reassurance, even when parameters fall well below optimal levels for conception.
There is a large, clinically relevant suboptimal range that is not flagged by standard guidelines but can significantly prolong time to pregnancy.
Male fertility factors contribute to up to 50% of fertility challenges and are frequently under-evaluated or oversimplified in care.
Fertility-focused care must distinguish between capacity to conceive and optimal chances of conception—especially when timing and cycle literacy are already in place.
Resources and Mentions
World Health Organization reference values for human semen characteristics

title: Does Skipping Breakfast Count As Intermittent Fasting? | FAMM Research Series
main_text:
Does Skipping Breakfast Count As Intermittent Fasting?
Intermittent fasting is a trending nutrition strategy—but many women unknowingly compromise their hormonal health by skipping breakfast. In this episode, Lisa explores how breakfast impacts ovulation, energy levels, progesterone production, and overall cycle health. Drawing on research highlighted in Real Food for Fertility, she discusses why a strategic eating window—with sufficient calories and macronutrients—is critical for fertility optimization, especially for active women or those TTC.
Timestamps
00:00 – Chart interpretation struggles & the real reason you’re undernourished
04:30 – Study overview: breakfast, energy intake & physical activity
10:15 – Skipping breakfast = accidental under-eating?
15:45 – Macronutrient losses: lower protein and carbs in breakfast skippers
20:30 – How meal timing affects cycle length, mucus & luteal phase health
25:00 – Intermittent fasting done right: Lisa’s clinical recommendations
30:45 – Coffee, hunger suppression, and menstrual cycle disruption
Key Takeaways
Skipping breakfast often leads to a 20–25% drop in total daily caloric intake—without compensatory eating later in the day.
Women who skip breakfast tend to consume significantly less protein and carbohydrates overall, impacting hormone production.
Under-eating—even unintentionally—reduces estrogen and progesterone levels, disrupting ovulation and the luteal phase.
Strategic intermittent fasting can be cycle-safe when using a 10-hour eating window with three complete meals.
Fertility-focused nutrition must consider macronutrient adequacy, timing, and the body’s physiological needs—not trends.
Resources and Mentions
Skipping breakfast reduces energy intake and physical activity in healthy women who are habitual breakfast eaters- A randomized crossover trial.

title: Protein, Blood Sugar, and PCOS: Nutrition for Fertility | Ep. 607
main_text:
Podcast Host:
Lisa Hendrickson is a certified fertility awareness educator and holistic reproductive health practitioner with over 20 years of experience. As the host of the Fertility Friday Podcast and author of The Fifth Vital Sign, Lisa helps women and practitioners understand the menstrual cycle as a powerful diagnostic tool for fertility, hormone health, and overall well-being.
Audio Player
00:00
00:00
Use Up/Down Arrow keys to increase or decrease volume.
Podcast: Play in new window | Download | Embed
Subscribe: Apple Podcasts | RSS
Episode Overview:
In Episode 607 of the Fertility Friday Podcast, Lisa Hendrickson-Jack kicks off the new year with an in-depth conversation with registered dietitian and researcher Lily Nichols. This episode explores the critical role of nutrition in fertility, using PCOS as a case study to explain why protein intake, blood sugar regulation, and macronutrient balance are essential for hormonal health, ovulation, and conception. Together, Lisa and Lily unpack current research, challenge common dietary myths, and explain how evidence-based nutrition supports both menstrual cycle health and pregnancy preparation.
Key Topics Covered:
Why protein intake matters for fertility and hormone balance
PCOS as a case study for metabolic health
Insulin resistance and ovulatory dysfunction
Blood sugar balance and menstrual cycle regularity
High-protein and lower-carb dietary approaches
Why calorie restriction disrupts hormones
The myth of minimum carbohydrate requirements
Preparing the body nutritionally for conception
Listener Takeaways:
Many women consistently under-eat protein
Protein supports blood sugar stability and ovulation
Insulin resistance plays a central role in PCOS
Improving metabolism often improves cycle regularity
Weight loss is not the primary goal for fertility support
Low-calorie and low-fat diets can suppress hormones
Adequate protein and fat help regulate cycles naturally
Key Moments (Timestamps & Detailed Summaries)
Why Nutrition Matters for Fertility ( 00:00 – 06:00 )
Lisa introduces the episode and explains why nutrition deserves more attention in fertility conversations. Lily shares why protein intake affects satiety, blood sugar, and hormone production, even before pregnancy is part of the picture.
Protein Intake and PCOS ( 06:00 – 18:00 )
Lily explains how higher-protein dietary approaches consistently show better outcomes in PCOS studies. She breaks down how protein supports blood sugar balance and why many successful PCOS interventions include higher protein and lower carbohydrate ratios.
Insulin Resistance and Ovulation ( 18:00 – 28:00 )
She outlines the study’s long duration, describing how participants were divided into control and intervention groups and instructed to significantly reduce dietary fat intake.
The Plate Method and Macronutrient Balance ( 28:00 – 38:00 )
Lily shares a practical way to structure meals by shifting the plate away from carb-heavy meals and toward adequate protein, fat, and vegetables. This approach improves blood sugar control without extreme restriction.
Why Weight Loss Is Not the Goal ( 38:00 – 48:00 )
Lisa and Lily discuss why focusing solely on weight loss often misses the root cause of fertility issues. Improving metabolic health, nutrient intake, and hormone balance leads to better outcomes than calorie restriction alone.
Carbohydrate Myths and Hormone Health ( 48:00 – 58:00 )
Lily addresses the claim that women need a minimum amount of carbohydrates to ovulate. She explains that the research behind this idea actually studied low-calorie diets, not low-carb diets, and why adequate energy intake matters more than carb quantity alone.
Blood Sugar Balance for Everyone ( 58:00 – 66:00 )
The discussion expands beyond PCOS, explaining why blood sugar regulation matters for all women trying to conceive. Even mild blood sugar elevations can delay conception and affect pregnancy outcomes.
Real Food for Fertility Overview ( 66:00 – 74:00 )
Lily summarizes the book’s approach, focusing on nutrient-dense foods, balanced macronutrients, and preparing the body for pregnancy rather than entering conception depleted.
TRANSCRIPT
+

title: Why Eating Enough Fat Matters for Hormones and the Menstrual Cycle | Ep. 606
main_text:
Podcast Host:
Lisa Hendrickson is a certified fertility awareness educator and holistic reproductive health practitioner with over 20 years of experience. As the host of the Fertility Friday Podcast and author of The Fifth Vital Sign, Lisa helps women and practitioners understand the menstrual cycle as a powerful diagnostic tool for fertility, hormone health, and overall well-being.
Audio Player
00:00
00:00
Use Up/Down Arrow keys to increase or decrease volume.
Podcast: Play in new window | Download | Embed
Subscribe: Apple Podcasts | RSS
Episode Overview:
In this episode, Lisa breaks down a long-term dietary study that offers important insight into why fat intake matters for hormone production and menstrual cycle health. While the study was originally designed to explore cancer risk, it unintentionally revealed how reducing dietary fat significantly lowers estrogen and progesterone levels. Lisa walks through the study design, the hormone changes observed, and what this means for women who are trying to balance hormones, support ovulation, or maintain a healthy cycle.
Key Topics Covered:
Why fat is essential for hormone production
A two-year low-fat diet intervention study
How reducing fat impacts estrogen and progesterone
Cholesterol is the building block for hormones
Low-fat diets and menstrual cycle disruption
Follicular development and ovulation physiology
Connections to hypothalamic amenorrhea
What this research means for real-life nutrition choices
Listener Takeaways:
Estrogen and progesterone are made from cholesterol
Low-fat diets can significantly reduce hormone output
Fat intake directly affects ovulation and luteal phase health
A 20 percent drop in estrogen signals impaired follicle development
A 33 percent drop in progesterone affects cycle quality
Many women unintentionally under-eat fat when dieting
Adequate fat intake supports hormone balance and fertility
Key Moments (Timestamps & Detailed Summaries)
Episode Introduction & Study Context ( 00:00 – 02:00 )
Lisa introduces the episode and explains why dietary fat is essential for hormone production. She previews the featured study and explains that it unintentionally reveals important insights into menstrual cycle health.
Why Researchers Studied Low-Fat Diets ( 02:00 – 04:00 )
Lisa explains that the study was designed to test whether lowering estrogen through a low-fat diet could reduce cancer risk—not to improve menstrual or hormonal health.
Two-Year Dietary Intervention Design ( 04:00 – 06:00 )
She outlines the study’s long duration, describing how participants were divided into control and intervention groups and instructed to significantly reduce dietary fat intake.
Actual Fat Intake Achieved ( 06:00 – 08:00 )
Lisa discusses how difficult it was for participants to reach extremely low fat targets and compares real-world fat intake between the control and test groups.
Hormone Changes After Two Years ( 08:00 – 10:30 )
She reviews the key findings: a 20% reduction in estradiol and a 33% reduction in progesterone among women consuming less dietary fat.
Fat, Cholesterol & Hormone Synthesis ( 10:30 – 12:30 )
Lisa explains how estrogen, progesterone, testosterone, cortisol, and vitamin D are all synthesized from cholesterol, reinforcing why fat intake is biologically necessary.
Estrogen, Follicular Development & Ovulation ( 12:30 – 14:30 )
She connects lower estrogen levels to impaired follicular growth, explaining how reduced estrogen can compromise ovulation quality.
Progesterone & Luteal Phase Health ( 14:30 – 16:30 )
Lisa explains how progesterone production depends on a healthy ovulation and why suppressed progesterone affects cycle stability and fertility.
What the Study Didn’t Measure ( 16:30 – 18:00 )
She critiques the lack of menstrual cycle tracking and the absence of cancer outcome data, explaining why conclusions must be interpreted carefully.
Final Takeaways & Practical Implications ( 18:00 – 19:00 )
Lisa summarizes why chronic low-fat diets can undermine hormone balance and reinforces the importance of adequate fat intake for menstrual and reproductive health.
TRANSCRIPT
+

title: Top 10 Fertility Awareness Lessons from 2025 | Ep. 605
main_text:
Podcast Host:
Lisa Hendrickson-Jack is a certified fertility awareness educator and holistic reproductive health practitioner with over 20 years of experience. As the host of the Fertility Friday Podcast and author of The Fifth Vital Sign, Lisa helps women and practitioners understand the menstrual cycle as a powerful diagnostic tool for fertility, hormone health, and overall well-being.
Audio Player
00:00
00:00
Use Up/Down Arrow keys to increase or decrease volume.
Podcast: Play in new window | Download | Embed
Subscribe: Apple Podcasts | RSS
Episode Overview:
In this milestone episode, Lisa reflects on the 2025 podcast year as Fertility Friday celebrates over 11 years on air and surpasses 600 episodes. Drawing from research-focused episodes, clinical experience, and practitioner work inside the Fertility Awareness Mastery Mentorship, Lisa shares her top 10 takeaways from the year. These insights highlight recurring themes around cycle literacy, ovulation, cervical mucus, hormonal birth control, male fertility, under-fueling, perimenopause, and why symptoms are meaningful signals—not random inconveniences.
Key Topics Covered:
Why the menstrual cycle is the most powerful personalized diagnostic tool
Cervical mucus vs. apps, algorithms, and AI predictions
The foundational role of ovulation in long-term health
Hormonal birth control and its measurable effects on hormones and sexual health
Under-eating, stress, and overtraining as drivers of cycle disruption
Timing and its critical role in conception
Male fertility is half of the fertility equation
Cycle literacy as a missing skill in women’s healthcare
Perimenopause as a transition, not a disease
Symptoms are meaningful feedback from the body
Listener Takeaways:
Charting your menstrual cycle provides real-time, individualized health data that no app can replace.
Ovulation is essential for bone, metabolic, cardiovascular, and hormone health—not just fertility.
Cervical mucus remains the most accurate indicator of fertility, even in a tech-driven world.
Hormonal birth control has wide-ranging effects on libido, nutrients, mood, and fertility that deserve open discussion.
Understanding your cycle helps you cut through health noise and make decisions based on your body’s actual response.
Key Moments (Timestamps & Detailed Summaries)
Podcast Milestones & Year-End Reflection ( 00:00 – 04:30 )
Lisa reflects on Fertility Friday’s 11th anniversary, over 600 episodes, and more than five million downloads. She explains why the end of the year is a natural point for reviewing themes, research, and lessons from the 2025 podcast season.
Takeaway #1: The Menstrual Cycle as a Diagnostic Tool ( 04:30 – 09:30 )
Lisa explains why the menstrual cycle provides unmatched personalized health data. She shares how charting reveals issues like PMS, spotting, pain, and irregular cycles that often go unaddressed in conventional healthcare.
Takeaway #2: Cervical Mucus Beats Apps and Algorithms ( 09:30 – 13:30 )
Despite advances in AI and fertility apps, Lisa emphasizes that real-time observations of cervical mucus remain more accurate. Apps cannot detect biological signs happening in the body, making foundational knowledge essential.
Takeaway #3: Ovulation Is Not Optional ( 13:30 – 17:30 )
Ovulation is framed as foundational to lifelong health, not just reproduction. Lisa discusses how ovulatory hormones support metabolism, mood, bone density, and cardiovascular health.
Takeaway #4: Hormonal Birth Control and the Pushback ( 17:30 – 23:00 )
Lisa reviews growing research on hormonal contraceptives and their effects on libido, vulvar tissues, nutrients, and fertility. She also discusses increasing resistance from medical and tech institutions as women ask more informed questions.
Takeaway #5: Under-Fueling, Stress, and Overtraining ( 23:00 – 27:30 )
Charting often reveals subtle cycle disruptions caused by undereating and excessive exercise. Lisa explains how delayed ovulation, short luteal phases, and low temperatures expose hidden energy deficits.
Takeaway #6: Timing Still Matters for Conception ( 27:30 – 31:30 )
Lisa stresses that accurate timing during the fertile window is essential. Many couples struggle to conceive simply because intercourse is mistimed—something charting quickly clarifies.
Takeaway #7: Male Fertility Is Half the Equation ( 31:30 – 35:30 )
Lisa highlights research linking sperm quality to conception success and miscarriage risk. She explains why male fertility must be evaluated when pregnancy doesn’t occur despite correct timing.
Takeaway #8: Cycle Literacy Is Missing in Healthcare ( 35:30 – 40:00 )
Lisa shares real-world examples of how lack of cycle knowledge leads to misdiagnosis and ineffective treatment. Charting allows practitioners to deliver personalized, responsive care.
Takeaway #9: Rethinking Perimenopause ( 40:00 – 42:30 )
Lisa discusses perimenopause as a natural transition rather than a disease. She explains how charting helps distinguish normal cycle changes from issues that need support.
Takeaway #10: Symptoms Are Meaningful Signals ( 42:30 – 44:00 )
Lisa closes by reinforcing that symptoms are feedback from the body. Charting helps women identify patterns, limits, and needs, cutting through misinformation and guesswork.
TRANSCRIPT
+

title: Does the Pill Shrink Vulvar Tissues? Examining the Clitoral Shrinkage Study | Ep. 604
main_text:
Podcast Host:
Lisa Hendrickson-Jack is a certified fertility awareness educator and holistic reproductive health practitioner with over 20 years of experience. As the host of the Fertility Friday Podcast and author of The Fifth Vital Sign, Lisa is known for translating complex research into practical insights that help women make informed decisions about hormonal health, fertility, and birth control.
Audio Player
00:00
00:00
Use Up/Down Arrow keys to increase or decrease volume.
Podcast: Play in new window | Download | Embed
Subscribe: Apple Podcasts | RSS
Episode Overview:
In this research-focused episode, Lisa dives into one of the most controversial studies ever discussed on the podcast: the study examining clitoral vascularization, clitoral volume, and sexual function in women using hormonal contraceptives. This episode breaks down what the study actually measured, why its findings sparked backlash, and why, despite a small sample size,e it raises serious questions about informed consent, sexual side effects, and the lack of follow-up research on hormonal birth control.
Key Topics Covered:
Why the clitoral shrinkage study became so controversial
How hormonal contraceptives affect testosterone, SHBG, and sexual function
Differences between the pill and the vaginal ring
Measured changes in clitoral volume and blood flow
Sexual side effects, including libido, lubrication, orgasm, and pain
Why the study has never been replicated
Informed consent and the ethics of contraceptive research
Whether these effects are permanent or reversible
Listener Takeaways:
Hormonal contraceptives can cause measurable, physical changes to sexual tissues, not just subjective symptoms.
Both the pill and the vaginal ring were associated with reduced clitoral volume after six months of use.
Sexual side effects like low libido and painful sex are supported by physiological data, not imagination.
A small sample size does not invalidate clinically significant findings, especially when effects are consistent.
Women deserve full, transparent information to make informed decisions about birth control use.
Key Moments (Timestamps & Detailed Summaries)
Introduction & Why This Study Matters ( 00:00 – 03:00 )
Lisa introduces the episode and explains why this study generated intense backlash when she first shared it publicly. She frames the discussion around informed consent and the responsibility to share uncomfortable research findings.
Background: Hormonal Birth Control and Sexual Function ( 03:00 – 08:00 )
Lisa reviews existing research linking hormonal contraceptives to reduced libido, orgasm changes, and pain with sex. She explains how suppression of ovulation affects estrogen, progesterone, and especially testosterone.
Study Design: What Did Researchers Measure? ( 08:00 – 14:30 )
The study followed 40 naturally cycling women aged 18–35, measuring clitoral volume, blood flow, hormones, and sexual function before and after six months on either the pill or the vaginal ring. Strict protocols were used to ensure accurate measurements.
Key Findings: Clitoral Volume & Blood Flow Changes ( 14:30 – 22:00 )
Both contraceptive methods led to significant reductions in clitoral volume nearly 20% in pill users and around 12–13% in ring users. Pill users also experienced reduced clitoral blood flow, while ring users did not.
Hormonal Mechanisms Behind the Changes ( 22:00 – 27:30 )
Lisa explains how suppressed testosterone and increased SHBG contribute to tissue atrophy, reduced lubrication, and decreased sexual response. She connects these findings to broader research on hormonal suppression.
Sexual Function Outcomes: Desire, Orgasm, and Pain ( 27:30 – 31:30 )
Both groups reported declines in libido and orgasm frequency, with more severe effects in pill users. Pain with intercourse and reduced lubrication were reported primarily in the pill group.
Why the Pill Appears Worse Than the Ring ( 31:30 – 35:30 )
Researchers theorized that oral estrogen causes greater hormonal disruption than the vaginal ring due to higher SHBG spikes and reduced free testosterone. Lisa emphasizes that “less harmful” does not mean harmless.
Criticism, Sample Size, and Missing Follow-Up Research ( 35:30 – 39:00 )
Lisa addresses the “small sample size” critique and questions why such striking findings were never followed up on. She discusses financial, ethical, and cultural barriers to deeper contraceptive research.
Are These Changes Permanent? ( 39:00 – 41:30 )
While the study did not examine recovery after stopping contraceptives, Lisa reviews existing post-pill research showing that hormone levels and sexual function often recover over time, though the transition can take months or years.
Informed Consent and Women’s Lived Experience ( 41:30 – 43:00 )
Lisa concludes by emphasizing that sharing research is not “anti-birth control.” It is about empowering women with accurate information so they can choose what works best for their bodies.
TRANSCRIPT
+

title: Do Women Feel More Attractive Before Ovulation? A Deep Dive into Cycle-Related Changes | Ep. 603
main_text:
Podcast Host:
Lisa Hendrickson-Jack is a fertility awareness educator, author of The Fifth Vital Sign, and host of the Fertility Friday Podcast. With over two decades of experience in menstrual cycle education, Lisa specializes in translating reproductive health research into practical insights for women and practitioners.
Audio Player
00:00
00:00
Use Up/Down Arrow keys to increase or decrease volume.
Podcast: Play in new window | Download | Embed
Subscribe: Apple Podcasts | RSS
Episode Overview:
In Episode 603, Lisa explores a compelling area of menstrual cycle research and evolutionary biology: how women perceive their own attractiveness, confidence, and sexual desire across the menstrual cycle. The episode centers on a large-scale 2021 study examining daily self-reports from nearly 900 women to assess changes in self-rated attractiveness, mood, sexual desire, and grooming behaviors. By comparing naturally cycling women with women using hormonal contraceptives, the study offers valuable insight into the role of ovulation and cyclical hormones in shaping women’s lived experiences.
Key Topics Covered:
Evolutionary biology and menstrual cycle research
Ovulation and changes in perceived attractiveness
Differences between naturally cycling women and hormonal contraceptive users
Self-rated attractiveness, confidence, and sexual desire across the cycle
Grooming behavior and appearance-related changes near ovulation
Mood and self-esteem fluctuations during the fertile window
What hormonal contraceptives may suppress or flatten the cyclical experience
Why cycle literacy matters for understanding behavior and health
Listener Takeaways
Ovulation is associated with measurable changes in how naturally cycling women perceive their own attractiveness, confidence, and sexual desire.
These cyclical shifts are driven by hormonal changes, not conscious behavior or social conditioning.
Mood, desire, and self-perception tend to peak near ovulation, though individual experiences vary widely.
Understanding cycle-related changes can help women normalize their experiences rather than pathologize them.
Fertility awareness offers valuable context for interpreting emotional, relational, and behavioral patterns across the cycle.
Key Moments (Timestamps & Detailed Summaries)
Introduction to Evolutionary Biology & Cycle Behavior ( 00:00 – 02:30 )
Lisa introduces the episode topic and frames the discussion within evolutionary biology. She explains why researchers study behavioral and emotional changes across the menstrual cycle and references prior research, including studies on attractiveness and ovulation. This sets the stage for understanding how hormones may influence self-perception and behavior.
Overview of the 2021 Large-Scale Diary Study ( 02:30 – 06:00 )
Lisa outlines the study design, including the sample size of 872 women and the comparison between naturally cycling women and hormonal contraceptive users. She explains how participants completed daily reports over 70 days and how researchers estimated cycle phases without direct ovulation testing. Strengths and limitations of the methodology are discussed.
Ovulation and Self-Perceived Attractiveness ( 06:00 – 10:00 )
This segment covers the study’s main finding: naturally cycling women reported feeling more attractive and sexually desirable in the days leading up to ovulation. Lisa explains why this result was consistent across multiple analyses and how it aligns with real-world cycle charting experiences.
Sexual Desire, Confidence, and Mood Changes ( 10:00 – 13:30 )
Lisa reviews findings related to sexual desire, self-esteem, and mood. She notes that while sexual desire increased most clearly around ovulation, mood and confidence also showed modest improvements. She emphasizes that these are trends, not rigid rules, and that individual experiences vary.
Grooming Behavior and External Expression ( 13:30 – 16:30 )
The conversation shifts to grooming behaviors such as clothing choices and appearance-related effort. Lisa explains that while there was a slight increase in grooming around ovulation, it was less pronounced than internal shifts like confidence and desire, suggesting perception changes precede behavior changes.
Hormonal Contraceptives and Flat Cycle Patterns ( 16:30 – 19:00 )
Lisa explains that women using hormonal contraceptives did not show cyclical changes in attractiveness, desire, or mood. She connects this finding to ovulation suppression and reinforces the idea that ovulation drives these cyclical experiences.
Clinical Implications and Cycle Literacy ( 19:00 – 22:00 )
Lisa discusses what these findings mean for women’s health and fertility awareness education. She highlights how cycle charting helps normalize experiences, identify trends, and recognize when symptoms may point to underlying imbalances rather than “just hormones.”
Nuance, Individuality, and Closing Reflections ( 22:00 – 24:00 )
The episode concludes with reflections on nuance and personalization. Lisa stresses that hormones influence tendencies, not destiny, and that understanding cyclical patterns can be empowering rather than limiting. She encourages listeners to view the menstrual cycle as valuable data, not a liability.
TRANSCRIPT
+

title: Painful Sex & Vaginismus: What Every Woman Should Know | Ep. 602
main_text:
Podcast Host:
Lisa Hendrickson-Jack is a certified fertility awareness educator and holistic reproductive health practitioner with over 20 years of experience. As the host of the Fertility Friday Podcast and author of The Fifth Vital Sign, Lisa helps women understand their cycles, hormones, and reproductive health so they can make informed decisions.
Audio Player
00:00
00:00
Use Up/Down Arrow keys to increase or decrease volume.
Podcast: Play in new window | Download | Embed
Subscribe: Apple Podcasts | RSS
Episode Overview:
In this episode of the Fertility Friday Podcast, Lisa Hendrickson-Jack sits down with Dr. Janelle Frederick, known as the Vagina Rehab Doctor, to discuss painful sex and vaginismus conditions that affect millions of women but are rarely discussed openly. Together, they explore why painful sex is more common than most people realize, the physical and emotional factors involved, and why pain should never be considered normal or something women are expected to endure. This conversation brings clarity, validation, and hope to couples struggling in silence.
Key Topics Covered:
What painful sex and vaginismus are and why they occur
How pelvic floor tension, fear, and pain interact
The prevalence of painful sex and why it’s often hidden
Cultural, educational, and religious influences on sexual pain
How pelvic floor therapy supports healing and recovery
The role of partners in the healing process
Why painful sex is treatable and not permanent
Listener Takeaways:
Painful sex is common, but it is not normal and should not be ignored
Vaginismus involves real, physical pelvic floor tension, not “just anxiety.”
Education, pelvic floor therapy, and nervous system support can restore pain-free intimacy
Healing is possible, often within a few months, with the right support
Couples are not alone, and shame should never prevent seeking help
Key Moments (Timestamps & Detailed Summaries)
Why This Conversation Matters ( 00:00 – 04:00 )
Lisa introduces the topic of painful sex and explains why it has rarely been addressed on the podcast despite how common it is. She emphasizes that pain during sex should never be normalized and sets the tone for an honest, stigma-free conversation.
Meet Dr. Janelle Frederick ( 04:00 – 09:00 )
Dr. Janelle shares her background as a pelvic floor physical therapist and explains how she came to specialize in sexual pain and vaginismus. She describes her clinical journey and why helping women experience pain-free intimacy became her focus.
How Common Is Painful Sex? ( 09:00 – 14:30 )
Dr. Janelle explains the prevalence of painful sex, noting that up to 75% of women experience it at some point in their lives. She discusses vaginismus specifically and why many women struggle silently due to shame or lack of awareness.
What Is Vaginismus? ( 14:30 – 22:00 )
This segment breaks down vaginismus as a pelvic floor disorder involving muscle tightness, pain, and often fear. Dr. Janelle clarifies misconceptions and explains why penetration can be painful or impossible for some women.
Education, Culture, and Silence ( 22:00 – 28:30 )
Lisa and Dr. Janelle discuss how poor sex education, cultural expectations, and religious messaging can contribute to painful sex. They explore how myths around virginity, tightness, and endurance perpetuate suffering.
When Sex Feels Like an Obligation ( 28:30 – 35:30 )
Dr. Janelle shares clinical experiences with women who endured pain for years out of a sense of duty. This segment highlights the emotional toll painful sex can have on relationships and self-worth.
How Pelvic Floor Therapy Helps ( 35:30 – 42:30 )
Dr. Janelle explains how pelvic floor therapy works, including muscle release, dilators, and nervous system regulation. She emphasizes that healing involves both physical and emotional retraining.
Partner Involvement and Support ( 42:30 – 47:00 )
Dr. Janelle shares realistic timelines for recovery, noting that many women experience significant improvement within two to three months when supported consistently.
How Long Does Healing Take? ( 47:00 – 50:00 )
The discussion shifts to the role partners can play in healing. Dr. Janelle explains how supportive partners can help with recovery and why intimacy-based healing can strengthen relationships.
Hope, Healing, and Final Reflections ( 50:00 – 52:00 )
The episode concludes with reassurance that painful sex is treatable and that women deserve pleasure, comfort, and agency in their bodies. Lisa reinforces the importance of seeking specialized support.
TRANSCRIPT
+

title: The Gut Health Dilemma: Why Elimination Diets Aren’t the Full Answer | Ep. 601
main_text:
Podcast Host:
Lisa Hendrickson-Jack is a certified fertility awareness educator and holistic reproductive health practitioner with over 20 years of experience. As the host of the Fertility Friday Podcast and author of The Fifth Vital Sign, Lisa empowers women to understand their menstrual cycles and optimize their hormone health. She’s a passionate advocate for informed choices about hormonal birth control and works to make fertility awareness accessible to all. Lisa’s mission is to help women take control of their fertility and overall health.
Audio Player
00:00
00:00
Use Up/Down Arrow keys to increase or decrease volume.
Podcast: Play in new window | Download | Embed
Subscribe: Apple Podcasts | RSS
Episode Overview:
In this episode of the Fertility Friday Podcast, Lisa Hendrickson-Jack talks with Hanna Aylward, a certified holistic health coach and functional gut health practitioner, about digestive issues that many women face, despite eating a clean diet. The conversation explores the root causes of bloating, food sensitivities, and other gut-related issues. They discuss the limitations of elimination diets and why they may only provide temporary relief, while addressing deeper gut health concerns is key to long-term healing. Tune in for practical insights on managing gut health and addressing the root causes of digestive discomfort.
Key Topics Covered:
The challenges of elimination diets and their temporary relief.
Root causes of digestive issues: low stomach acid, gut dysbiosis, and gallbladder/liver function.
The role of stress, trauma, and other factors in gut health.
The connection between hormonal contraceptives and gut health disruption.
The importance of addressing root causes before relying on dietary restrictions.
Listener Takeaways:
Elimination diets may temporarily ease symptoms, but don’t address the underlying issues that cause digestive discomfort.
Chronic bloating and digestive problems can stem from factors like low stomach acid, gut dysbiosis, and imbalances in gut bacteria.
Over-reliance on restrictive diets like low FODMAP can cause long-term food sensitivities and worsen gut health.
Supporting gut health involves more than just removing problematic foods—it’s about understanding the deeper factors affecting digestion and taking a holistic approach to healing.
Hormonal contraceptives can impact gut health, contributing to issues like bloating, yeast infections, and bacterial imbalances in the gut.
Key Moments (Timestamps & Detailed Summaries)
Introduction to the Episode & Sponsor ( 00:00 – 04:30 )
Lisa introduces the episode and mentions the Fertility Awareness Mastery Mentorship Certification program. She emphasizes that this is an opportunity for women’s health professionals to master advanced menstrual charting and deepen their understanding of fertility awareness.
Introduction to Hanna Aylward & Her Journey ( 04:30 – 10:00 )
Hanna shares her personal story of struggling with digestive issues and how her experience led her to study gut health. She discusses how restrictive diets like elimination diets only provided partial relief and how understanding the root causes of gut issues led her to a better solution.
Understanding Root Causes of Digestive Issues ( 10:00 – 15:30 )
Hanna explains how issues like low stomach acid, gut dysbiosis, and imbalances in gut bacteria contribute to chronic bloating and discomfort. She discusses how these imbalances can make foods like apples, garlic, and onions difficult to digest.
The Role of Stress, Trauma, and Lifestyle Factors ( 15:30 – 22:00 )
Lisa and Hanna discuss how chronic stress, childhood trauma, and lifestyle habits like undereating or over-exercising can contribute to gut dysfunction. Hanna explains how these factors lead to gut dysbiosis and digestive problems.
The Connection Between Hormonal Contraceptives and Gut Health ( 22:00 – 27:30 )
Hanna talks about the impact of hormonal contraceptives on gut health, including how they disrupt the gut microbiome. She highlights research showing that hormonal birth control, including IUDs, can lead to bacterial imbalances and digestive issues.
Understanding Histamine Sensitivity and Food Sensitivities ( 27:30 – 33:30 )
The conversation shifts to histamine sensitivity and the rise of food sensitivities, especially in relation to estrogen levels. Hanna explains how hormonal fluctuations can exacerbate sensitivities and discusses how addressing these sensitivities involves more than just eliminating certain foods.
The Downside of Restrictive Diets (FODMAPs, Low Histamine, and More) ( 33:30 – 40:30 )
Hanna discusses the potential drawbacks of long-term restrictive diets like low FODMAP and low histamine diets. While they may provide short-term relief, they don’t address the root causes of digestive issues and can worsen sensitivities over time.
Improving Digestion: Practical Tips ( 40:30 – 45:30 )
Hanna shares practical tips for improving digestion, including the importance of deep breathing before meals, chewing food thoroughly, and being present during meals. She also emphasizes the importance of gut microbiome diversity and consuming polyphenol-rich foods.
When to Seek Professional Help and Testing ( 45:30 – 51:30 )
Lisa and Hanna talk about how to know when it’s time to seek help from a practitioner for deeper testing and support. They discuss the value of lab tests, gut health assessments, and working with a professional who understands the root causes of digestive issues.
Final Thoughts on Gut Health and the Need for a Holistic Approach ( 51:30 – 56:00 )
Hanna shares her final thoughts on gut health, urging listeners not to accept feeling “normal” when they are dealing with digestive discomfort. She encourages women to seek out support, look for the root causes, and avoid the trap of food restriction that leads to further issues.
Closing & Call to Action ( 56:00 – 59:00 )
Lisa wraps up the episode by reminding listeners about the Fertility Awareness Mastery Mentorship Certification and encourages them to explore the resources Hanna offers, including her gut health quiz
TRANSCRIPT
+

title: Is Fertility Awareness Too Difficult? User Behavior, Intention & Effectiveness | Ep. 600
main_text:
Podcast Host:
Lisa Hendrickson-Jack is a certified fertility awareness educator and holistic reproductive health practitioner with over 20 years of experience.
Audio Player
00:00
00:00
Use Up/Down Arrow keys to increase or decrease volume.
Podcast: Play in new window | Download | Embed
Subscribe: Apple Podcasts | RSS
Episode Overview:
In Episode 600 of the Fertility Friday Podcast, Lisa Hendrickson-Jack explores a critical question often raised by both users and practitioners: Is fertility awareness too complicated to use effectively? Drawing from a real-world research study on fertility awareness users, Lisa examines the relationship between stated intention, user behavior, and pregnancy outcomes. This episode highlights why unintended pregnancies are rarely due to method failure and instead stem from user behavior, shifting intentions, and lack of structure. The discussion is especially relevant for women’s health professionals who teach fertility awareness-based methods and want to support clients with clarity and confidence.
Key Topics Covered:
Whether fertility awareness is inherently difficult to use
The difference between method failure and user failure
How intention and behavior influence pregnancy outcomes
Key findings from a real-world fertility awareness study
Why pre-ovulatory management is the cornerstone of effectiveness
The role of structure, training, and practitioner guidance
Why do double-check sympto-thermal methods show higher efficacy
Listener Takeaways:
Fertility awareness is not too difficult when taught with the right structure
Most unintended pregnancies occur due to user behavior, not method failure
Intention can shift mid-cycle and must be openly discussed
Clear fertile window boundaries reduce confusion and risk
Practitioner training is essential to support real-life complexity
High efficacy depends on managing the pre-ovulatory phase accurately
Key Moments (Timestamps & Detailed Summaries)
Introducing the Central Question ( 00:00 – 02:30 )
Lisa introduces the episode’s guiding question: Is fertility awareness too complicated? She explains why this topic matters for both personal users and women’s health professionals.
Overview of the Research Study ( 02:30 – 05:30 )
Lisa introduces the study examining pregnancy intentions, behaviors, and outcomes among users of a mucus-only fertility awareness method. She explains why real-world data offers valuable insights.
Study Population & Participant Demographics ( 05:30 – 08:30 )
Details of the study population are reviewed, including age, relationship status, religious background, and experience level with fertility awareness methods.
Intention vs. Behavior in Real Life ( 08:30 – 12:00 )
Lisa discusses how intentions are not static and can change mid-cycle. She explains why this mismatch between stated intention and behavior is common in clinical practice.
Fertile-Day Intercourse Despite Avoidance Intentions ( 12:00 – 15:30 )
Key findings show that nearly one-third of cycles labeled as “avoiding” still included intercourse on known fertile days. Lisa explains how this impacts pregnancy outcomes.
Pregnancy Outcomes & Method Effectiveness ( 15:30 – 18:30 )
Lisa breaks down conception rates among those trying to conceive, those avoiding, and those ambivalent. She highlights the extremely low true method failure rate (.3%).
The Importance of Accurate Charting & Data Recording ( 18:30 – 21:00 )
The episode addresses the issue of incomplete intercourse tracking and why missing data undermines both research accuracy and client support.
Is Fertility Awareness Too Complicated? ( 21:00 – 23:30 )
Lisa reframes the question, emphasizing that fertility awareness itself isn’t too complex; rather, lack of structure and clarity leads to confusion.
The Intention Scale & Human Nuance ( 23:30 – 26:00 )
Lisa introduces the intention scale and explains why most people fall somewhere in the middle, rather than fully avoiding or fully trying to conceive.
Why Double-Check Sympto-Thermal Methods Work Best ( 26:00 – 29:00 )
Lisa explains why methods using both cervical mucus and temperature offer higher efficacy by clearly defining the fertile window and reducing gray areas.
Practitioner Responsibility & Training ( 29:00 – 31:30 )
This section highlights why charting your own cycle is not sufficient preparation for teaching others and why practitioner training is essential.
Fertility Awareness as a Planning Tool ( 31:30 – 33:00 )
Lisa explains how fertility awareness supports preconception health, cycle normalization, and informed family planning in ways hormonal methods cannot.
Final Reflections & Core Message ( 33:00 – 34:00 )
The episode concludes with the key takeaway: fertility awareness works when paired with the right system, structure, education, and practitioner support.
TRANSCRIPT
+

title: How Midwives Can Integrate Fertility Awareness Into Client Care | Ep. 599
main_text:
Podcast Host:
Lisa Hendrickson-Jack is a fertility awareness educator, author of The Fifth Vital Sign, and host of the Fertility Friday Podcast
Audio Player
00:00
00:00
Use Up/Down Arrow keys to increase or decrease volume.
Podcast: Play in new window | Download | Embed
Subscribe: Apple Podcasts | RSS
Episode Overview:
In Episode 599 of the Fertility Friday Podcast, Lisa Hendrickson-Jack speaks with licensed midwife and FAM practitioner Kate Chantry about how fertility awareness can be effectively integrated into midwifery care. This conversation explores postpartum charting, working with clients who prefer natural family planning, addressing misconceptions about fertility awareness, and supporting women through cycle irregularities and preconception health. Kate shares her personal journey with charting, her professional evolution as a midwife, and how fertility awareness has expanded her ability to support women and families with clarity and confidence.
Key Topics Covered:
Integrating fertility awareness into midwifery practice
Postpartum charting and breastfeeding considerations
Common misconceptions about the rhythm method
Fertility awareness as a non-hormonal option for families
Supporting preconception and cycle normalization
Practitioner confidence through structured chart interpretation
Fertility awareness within conservative and Amish communities
Listener Takeaways:
Fertility awareness can be seamlessly incorporated into midwifery care
Proper education distinguishes fertility awareness from the rhythm method
Charting provides valuable insight into postpartum and irregular cycles
Practitioner training builds confidence and clarity when supporting clients
Fertility awareness empowers both clients and providers with informed choices
Key Moments (Timestamps & Detailed Summaries)
Introduction & Episode Focus ( 00:00 – 02:30 )
Lisa introduces the episode and explains why fertility awareness is a powerful addition to midwifery care.
She outlines how charting supports postpartum clients, family planning, and informed cycle education.
The episode is positioned as both practical and reflective for women’s health professionals.
Introducing Guest Kate Chantry ( 02:30 – 05:30 )
Kate shares her background as a licensed midwife, bodyworker, and mother practicing in rural Wisconsin.
She describes her roots in home birth and community-centered care.
This foundation shaped her interest in supporting women holistically across the reproductive lifespan.
First Period & Early Cycle Experiences ( 05:30 – 10:30 )
Kate reflects on getting her first period and early beliefs about menstruation as limiting or burdensome.
She discusses irregular cycles, a brief loss of menstruation, and learning the role of nutrition and exercise.
These early experiences influenced how she later approached cycle health with clients.
Discovering Charting in Midwifery School ( 10:30 – 14:30 )
Kate describes her first exposure to cycle charting during midwifery training.
She explains why the mucus interpretation felt confusing and inconsistent at first.
Later education helped her understand fertility signs with greater clarity and confidence.
Avoiding Hormonal Birth Control & Early Fertility Experiences ( 14:30 – 18:00 )
Kate shares her experience of never using hormonal birth control due to personal and cultural values.
She explains relying on charting and condoms before marriage.
A later unplanned pregnancy highlighted the limitations of rhythm-based assumptions.
Postpartum Charting Challenges ( 18:00 – 21:00 )
The discussion explores how breastfeeding, sleep disruption, and inconsistent temperatures affect charting.
Kate explains why postpartum cycles are especially difficult without proper guidance.
Improved mucus understanding made fertility awareness more accessible during this phase.
Partner Confidence & Shared Understanding ( 21:00 – 24:00 )
Kate explains how consistent charting helped rebuild trust with her husband after prior complications.
Seeing clear data improved confidence in fertility awareness as a reliable method.
This shift changed how fertility decisions were approached as a couple.
Applying Fertility Awareness With Clients ( 24:00 – 28:00 )
Kate discusses moving from simply referring clients to actively guiding them through charting.
She explains how asking better, more targeted questions improves outcomes.
The work became more effective once she could interpret and apply chart data directly.
Midwifery, Postpartum Care & Preconception Support ( 28:00 – 31:00 )
Lisa and Kate discuss how fertility awareness strengthens postpartum counseling.
They highlight inter-pregnancy spacing, nutrient replenishment, and cycle normalization.
Charting becomes a practical tool for long-term reproductive planning.
Rhythm Method vs. Fertility Awareness ( 31:00 – 33:00 )
They clarify why fertility awareness is often mistaken for the rhythm method.
Lack of education and structure leads many women to believe the method “doesn’t work.”
Proper instruction dramatically changes effectiveness and confidence.
Practitioner Training & Client Success ( 33:00 – 34:30 )
Kate shares how structured training improved her ability to support complex cases.
She explains why charting your own cycle is not enough to teach others.
Professional education equips practitioners to meet diverse client needs.
Final Reflections & Encouragement ( 34:30 – 35:00 )
Kate reflects on how fertility awareness expanded her midwifery practice.
She emphasizes restoring trust in the menstrual cycle as a vital sign.
The episode closes with encouragement for practitioners to embrace cycle education.
TRANSCRIPT
+

title: Do Organ Meats Boost Male Fertility? | FAM Research Series
main_text:
Podcast Host:
Lisa Hendrickson-Jack is a certified fertility awareness educator and host of the Fertility Friday Podcast, specializing in menstrual cycle science, fertility research, and evidence-based reproductive health education.
Audio Player
00:00
00:00
Use Up/Down Arrow keys to increase or decrease volume.
Podcast: Play in new window | Download | Embed
Subscribe: Apple Podcasts | RSS
Episode Overview:
In Episode 598, Lisa takes a deep dive into a male fertility research study examining meat consumption and sperm quality. Using this study as a case example, she explains how researcher bias can influence hypotheses, abstracts, and conclusions—sometimes obscuring the most meaningful findings. The episode highlights how organ meats were strongly associated with improved sperm count, concentration, and motility, despite these results being downplayed by the study authors.
Key Topics Covered:
Research bias and how it shapes fertility study conclusions
Overview of the study: Meat Intake and Reproductive Parameters Among Young Men
Differences between processed meat, unprocessed red meat, and organ meats
Organ meat consumption and improvements in sperm parameters
Nutrient density and its role in male fertility
Why abstracts often omit critical findings
How to critically interpret nutrition and fertility research
Listener Takeaways:
Research findings are often filtered through the researcher’s original assumptions
Organ meats showed statistically significant improvements in sperm quality
Unprocessed red meat was not associated with poorer sperm parameters
Processed meat results may reflect broader dietary patterns
Reading beyond the abstract is essential for understanding fertility research
Nutrient-dense foods play a key role in supporting male fertility
Key Moments (Timestamps & Detailed Summaries)
Introduction: Bias in Fertility Research ( 00:00 – 02:00 )
Lisa introduces the theme of research bias and explains why understanding a researcher’s perspective matters.
She outlines how the same data can be interpreted very differently depending on assumptions.
Study Overview & Original Hypothesis ( 02:00 – 04:30 )
Lisa reviews the study design, population, and meat categories analyzed.
She explains the researchers’ expectation that red meat would negatively affect sperm quality..
Processed vs Unprocessed Red Meat Findings ( 04:30 – 08:30 )
Processed meat intake was associated with a lower total sperm count.
Unprocessed red meat showed no negative association and slight, non-significant improvements in sperm parameters.
Organ Meats & Significant Sperm Improvements ( 08:30 – 12:30 )
Organ meat intake was linked to large, statistically significant increases in sperm count, concentration, and motility.
Lisa explains why these findings are biologically plausible given the nutrient profile of organ meats.
What the Abstract Left Out ( 12:30 – 15:30 )
Lisa reveals that the abstract omitted the most important positive findings.
She explains how the authors focused on results that supported their hypothesis.
Nutrients That Support Male Fertility ( 15:30 – 19:00 )
Lisa connects organ meats to key fertility nutrients like vitamin A, zinc, CoQ10, and carnitine.
She explains how these nutrients directly support sperm development and function.
Explaining Away Contradictory Results ( 19:00 – 22:00 )
The researchers dismiss the positive organ meat findings as chance or confounding.
Lisa highlights how bias can lead researchers to minimize results they didn’t expect.
Final Thoughts on Reading Research Critically ( 22:00 – 24:00 )
Lisa encourages listeners to read full studies, not just abstracts.
She emphasizes curiosity, skepticism, and context when interpreting fertility research.
TRANSCRIPT
+

title: Are Women Ditching Birth Control for Fertility Awareness?
main_text:
Podcast Host:
Lisa Hendrickson-Jack is a certified fertility awareness educator and holistic reproductive health practitioner.
Audio Player
00:00
00:00
Use Up/Down Arrow keys to increase or decrease volume.
Podcast: Play in new window | Download | Embed
Subscribe: Apple Podcasts | RSS
Episode Overview:
In this episode of the Fertility Friday Podcast, Lisa analyzes a UK-based study examining contraceptive use among women seeking abortion care between 2018 and 2023. She critically evaluates how fertility awareness–based methods (FABMs) are defined, measured, and portrayed in reproductive health research, and challenges the narrative that fertility awareness is driving unintended pregnancy. The episode offers a data-driven breakdown of what the study actually shows—and what it overlooks.
Key Topics Covered
UK abortion clinic data comparing contraceptive use in 2018 vs 2023
Misclassification of fertility awareness methods and period-tracking apps
Declines in hormonal and long-acting contraceptive use
The rise in reported “no method” use
Typical use vs perfect use effectiveness across methods
Research bias and interpretation of reproductive health data
Why dissatisfaction with hormonal contraception matters
Listener Takeaways
Period-tracking apps are not the same as fertility awareness–based methods
Most unintended pregnancies in the study occurred with no contraception used
Research conclusions depend heavily on definitions and framing
Hormonal contraception is not failure-proof under typical use
Fertility awareness can reduce risk compared to using no method at all
Critical thinking is essential when interpreting reproductive health studies
Key Moments (Timestamps & Detailed Summaries)
Episode Introduction & Research Question ( 00:00 – 01:30 )
Lisa introduces the episode’s central question: Are women abandoning birth control for fertility awareness?
She explains why a newly published UK study caught her attention.
The episode sets up a critical examination of how data is framed and interpreted.
Overview of the UK Abortion Study ( 01:30 – 04:00 )
Lisa outlines the study design comparing abortion clinic data from 2018 and 2023.
She explains the role of BPAS and how contraceptive use was self-reported.
The study’s intention to avoid COVID-related data distortion is discussed.
Defining “Fertility Awareness” in Research ( 04:00 – 07:00 )
Reported use of period apps increased from 0.4% to 2.5%.
Hormonal and long-acting contraceptive use declined significantly.
The most notable increase was in women reporting no method at all.
Study Results: What Changed From 2018 to 2023 ( 07:00 – 10:00 )
Reported use of period apps increased from 0.4% to 2.5%.
Hormonal and long-acting contraceptive use declined significantly.
The most notable increase was in women reporting no method at all.
The Overlooked Majority: No Method Use ( 10:00 – 13:000 )
Lisa highlights that 70% of women in 2023 reported using no contraception.
She questions why this finding received less attention than app usage.
The implications of no-method use are contrasted with known pregnancy risk data.
Typical Use Failure Rates Explained ( 13:00 – 16:00 )
The episode breaks down typical vs perfect use across methods.
Lisa explains why FABMs range widely in effectiveness.
She compares these rates with hormonal contraceptive typical-use data.
Research Bias & Misplaced Blame ( 16:00 – 19:00 )
Lisa critiques the study’s conclusion that FABMs are the problem.
She explains how studying only unintended pregnancies skews conclusions.
The difference between user error and method failure is clarified.
Education Gaps in Contraception Use ( 19:00 – 22:00 )
Lisa reflects on changes in sex education across generations.
She discusses declining education around non-hormonal methods.
The lack of instruction on correct method use is identified as a core issue.
Why Women Are Leaving Hormonal Birth Control ( 22:00 – 26:00 )
The episode explores dissatisfaction and side effects of hormonal contraception.
Lisa references data showing high discontinuation rates within one year.
She challenges the idea that social media is the primary driver of change.
Final Thoughts & Critical Research Reading ( 26:00 – 29:00 )
Lisa emphasizes the importance of questioning assumptions in research.
She encourages listeners to examine definitions, populations, and framing.
The episode closes with a call for more honest, nuanced reproductive health analysis.
TRANSCRIPT

title: Sex Bias in Science: How Research Fails Women | Fertility Friday Podcast Ep. 596
main_text:
Podcast Host:
Lisa Hendrickson-Jack is a fertility awareness educator and host of the Fertility Friday Podcast, known for translating reproductive health research into practical education.
Audio Player
00:00
00:00
Use Up/Down Arrow keys to increase or decrease volume.
Podcast: Play in new window | Download | Embed
Subscribe: Apple Podcasts | RSS
Episode Overview:
In Episode 596, Lisa examines how sex bias in scientific research has shaped medicine, drug testing, and health outcomes. Drawing from animal studies and human trials, she explains how female physiology—especially the menstrual cycle—has been excluded from study design. The episode highlights why this bias persists, how it affects women’s health outcomes, and what meaningful research reform could look like.
Key Topics Covered
Historical exclusion of females from scientific research
Male physiology as the default research model
Menstrual cycle variability and flawed study designs
Drug testing and hormone-related side effects
Sex bias in animal and human studies
Why women experience higher adverse drug reactions
Recommendations for improving research methodology
Listener Takeaways
Most biomedical research is still based on male biology
Female hormonal cycles are often ignored in study design
Drug safety data frequently fail to account for women’s physiology
Spot-testing hormones misses critical cycle-related changes
Research reform requires studying women as women
Understanding bias improves how we interpret scientific claims
Key Moments (Timestamps & Detailed Summaries)
Introduction to the Episode & Research Context ( 00:00 – 01:30 )
Lisa introduces the episode as a continuation of her conversation with Dr. Sarah Hill. She outlines the core issue of sex bias in science, explaining that much of modern biomedical research has been based on male physiology and male animals, with major implications for women’s health.
Why Women Have Been Excluded From Scientific Research ( 01:30 – 03:30 )
Lisa explains how female animals and women have been systematically excluded from research since the 1930s due to assumptions about hormonal variability. She emphasizes how this exclusion has produced incomplete, misleading, and often unsafe conclusions.
Male Physiology as the Default Scientific Standard ( 03:30 – 05:30 )
This segment explores how male biology became the assumed “default” in research. Lisa explains how findings were generalized to women without proper testing, shaping medical education, drug development, and clinical care.
The Study: Sex Bias in Animal and Biomedical Research ( 05:30 – 07:45 )
Lisa introduces the review paper Unmasking the Adverse Impacts of Sex Bias on Science and Research in Animal Welfare. She summarizes key findings, including that roughly 80% of animals used in research are male, and that sex-based analysis is rarely performed even when females are included.
Why Including Females Isn’t Enough ( 07:45 – 09:30 )
Lisa explains that simply adding female subjects does not solve the problem if results are not analyzed by sex. She discusses how failing to report sex-specific outcomes limits clinical relevance and masks meaningful differences.
Ovary Removal and Flawed Research Practices ( 09:30 – 11:00 )
This section covers the practice of removing ovaries from female animals to reduce hormonal variability. Lisa explains why this undermines the entire purpose of studying sex differences and produces data that do not reflect real female physiology.
Studying Women at “Low Hormone” Phases ( 11:00 – 13:00 )
Lisa discusses how women are often studied only during the early follicular phase of the menstrual cycle. She explains why avoiding high-estrogen and high-progesterone phases prevents researchers from identifying important hormone–drug interactions.
PMDD Research and the Limits of Spot Hormone Testing ( 13:00 – 15:30 )
Lisa revisits PMDD research that dismissed progesterone involvement based on a single mid-luteal measurement. She explains why one-time testing fails to capture late-luteal hormone changes that are clinically relevant.
Why Better Study Design Requires More Effort ( 15:30 – 18:00 )
Lisa outlines what an improved research design could look like, including cycle tracking, ovulation confirmation, and multiple testing points. She acknowledges increased complexity and cost but argues that accuracy and safety must come first.
Animal Welfare and the Cost of Sex Bias ( 18:00 – 20:00 )
The episode highlights how excluding female animals leads to unnecessary animal waste. Lisa explains how better inclusion could improve scientific validity while also reducing ethical and welfare concerns.
Why This Matters for Women’s Health Today ( 20:00 – 22:30 )
Lisa connects research bias to real-world outcomes, including unexpected side effects, misprescribing, and higher adverse drug reactions in women. She emphasizes that many medications were never adequately tested across the menstrual cycle.
Reframing Female Biology in Science ( 22:30 – 24:00 )
Lisa argues that female physiology should be treated as foundational rather than inconvenient. She explains that embracing hormonal cycles is essential for meaningful scientific progress.
Closing Thoughts & Call to Critical Thinking ( 24:00 – 25:00 )
Lisa encourages listeners to read research critically, look beyond abstracts, and question study design and assumptions. She emphasizes that progress begins with demanding better, more honest science.
TRANSCRIPT
+

title: AMH and Ovarian Reserve: Debunking Myths and Clarifying Facts | Ep. 595
main_text:
Podcast Host:
Lisa Hendrickson-Jack is a certified fertility awareness educator and holistic reproductive health practitioner. As the host of the Fertility Friday Podcast, Lisa empowers women to understand their menstrual cycles and fertility, helping them make informed decisions about their reproductive health.
Audio Player
00:00
00:00
Use Up/Down Arrow keys to increase or decrease volume.
Podcast: Play in new window | Download | Embed
Subscribe: Apple Podcasts | RSS
Episode Overview:
In this episode of the Fertility Friday Podcast, Lisa dives deep into Anti-Müllerian Hormone (AMH) and ovarian reserve testing, discussing the misconceptions surrounding AMH and its use in fertility assessments. Lisa clarifies the role of AMH in understanding ovarian reserve, why it’s often misunderstood, and what it truly indicates. This episode is essential for women who are trying to conceive, struggling with fertility issues, or practitioners who want to better support their clients through AMH-related concerns.
Key Topics Covered
What AMH (Anti-Müllerian Hormone) is and how it relates to ovarian reserve
Common misconceptions about AMH, including its ability to predict fertility and menopause
How AMH levels fluctuate with age and what they really tell us about a woman’s fertility
The link between AMH levels and conditions like PCOS and endometriosis
The role of AMH in Assisted Reproductive Technology (ART), such as IVF, and how it helps predict ovarian response
Why AMH is not a reliable predictor of natural conception or pregnancy success
The importance of age and overall health in fertility, despite AMH levels
Research findings on AMH’s limitations and its use in clinical practice
Listener Takeaways
AMH is not a crystal ball; it estimates ovarian reserve but does not predict fertility or the likelihood of pregnancy
A low AMH level does not guarantee infertility, and women with low AMH can still conceive naturally
Egg quality matters more than quantity, and lifestyle changes can improve fertility regardless of AMH levels
AMH is most useful for planning IVF treatments and adjusting ovarian stimulation protocols, not for predicting natural conception outcomes
Fertility declines with age, but AMH is only one part of the picture and does not reflect egg health
Key Moments (Timestamps & Detailed Summaries)
Introduction to AMH and Ovarian Reserve ( 00:00 – 02:00 )
Lisa introduces the topic of AMH and explains why it is important for women and fertility practitioners to understand the truth about this hormone. She discusses how misconceptions around AMH can lead to unnecessary fear and stress for women trying to conceive.
What is AMH and What Does it Measure? ( 02:00 – 06:30 )
Lisa breaks down the role of AMH in the body, explaining how it reflects ovarian reserve and the number of eggs a woman has left. She outlines the connection between AMH and the antral follicle count, explaining how this measure has evolved over time.
Common Misconceptions About AMH ( 06:30 – 09:30 )
Lisa debunks myths about AMH, including its ability to predict fertility and menopause. She explains why AMH levels are not static and how they can be influenced by factors like diet, stress, and certain health conditions such as PCOS and endometriosis.
AMH and Its Role in IVF Treatments ( 09:30 – 13:30 )
The conversation shifts to how AMH is used in ART, particularly IVF, to help clinicians determine the appropriate dosage for ovarian stimulation. Lisa explains how AMH levels correlate with egg retrieval and how it helps predict ovarian response during IV
The Role of Age in Fertility and AMH ( 13:30 – 17:00 )
Lisa discusses the impact of age on fertility, stressing that while AMH can indicate ovarian reserve, it cannot predict a woman’s ability to conceive naturally. She explains how the decline in fertility with age is not solely reflected by AMH but is influenced by many other factor
How to Focus on Egg Quality Over Quantity ( 17:00 – 19:30 )
Lisa emphasizes that the health of the eggs is more important than the quantity, and that women should focus on improving egg quality through diet, supplementation, and lifestyle changes rather than relying solely on AMH number
AMH, Natural Conception, and Research Findings ( 19:30 – 22:00 )
The discussion continues on the limitations of AMH in predicting natural conception, with Lisa referencing studies showing that women with low AMH levels can still conceive naturally. She stresses the importance of looking at the whole picture when assessing fertility.
Conclusion and Final Thoughts ( 22:00 – 24:00 )
Lisa wraps up the episode by reinforcing the idea that AMH is just one part of the fertility puzzle. She encourages women to focus on supporting their fertility through healthy lifestyle choices, and for practitioners to keep up-to-date with current research on fertility and ovarian reserve.
TRANSCRIPT
+
