title: What Is The Role Of Vitamin A In Sperm Production | Ep. 594
main_text:
Podcast Host:
Lisa Hendrickson is a certified fertility awareness educator and holistic reproductive health practitioner with over 20 years of experience. As the host of the Fertility Friday Podcast and author of The Fifth Vital Sign, Lisa helps women and practitioners understand the menstrual cycle as a powerful diagnostic tool for fertility, hormone health, and overall well-being.
Audio Player
00:00
00:00
Use Up/Down Arrow keys to increase or decrease volume.
Podcast: Play in new window | Download | Embed
Subscribe: Apple Podcasts | RSS
Episode Overview:
In this episode of the Fertility Friday Podcast, Lisa explores the crucial role of vitamin A in sperm production and male fertility. Focusing on research, particularly a narrative review on retinoic acid and its influence on spermatogenesis, she highlights the vital connection between nutrition and male reproductive health. The episode emphasizes why vitamin A deficiency can lead to cessation of sperm production and discusses the significant impact of consuming vitamin A-rich foods like liver on sperm health.
Key Topics Covered:
The importance of vitamin A in sperm and testosterone production
Retinoic acid as a key factor in spermatogenesis
Animal and human studies on the effects of vitamin A deficiency
The role of nutrition in supporting sperm health
The implications of retinoic acid in male fertility conditions
Research on organ meat consumption and sperm quality
The potential use of vitamin A as a contraceptive method
The link between vitamin A and oxidative stress in male fertility
Listener Takeaways:
Vitamin A is essential for optimal sperm production.
Liver and other organ meats are rich sources of vitamin A.
Deficiency in vitamin A can halt sperm production entirely.
Retinoic acid pulses regulate sperm production on a daily basis.
Animal studies show the reversibility of sperm production when vitamin A is reintroduced.
Regular consumption of vitamin A-rich foods can improve sperm quality.
Low sperm counts and poor quality can potentially be improved with vitamin A supplementation.
Key Moments (Timestamps & Detailed Summaries)
Episode Introduction ( 00:00 – 05:00 )
Lisa introduces the episode’s topic, explaining the importance of vitamin A in sperm production and its overlooked role in male fertility. She sets the stage for discussing the research on retinoic acid, the active form of vitamin A, and its pivotal role in spermatogenesis. This episode centers around how vitamin A directly impacts both sperm and testosterone production.
Vitamin A’s Impact on Male Reproductive Health ( 05:00 – 08:00 )
The episode dives into the findings from a narrative review that highlights how retinoic acid plays a crucial role in spermatogenesis. Lisa explains how vitamin A deficiency can essentially stop sperm production entirely in animal models. She emphasizes that this nutrient is essential for maintaining healthy sperm development and testosterone levels, making it fundamental to male fertility.
The Role of Vitamin A in Spermatogenesis ( 08:00 – 10:00 )
Lisa breaks down the role of retinoic acid in the process of sperm production. Retinoic acid, derived from vitamin A, acts as an “on switch” for sperm development by regulating gene expression within the testes. This section elaborates on how retinoic acid pulses guide sperm production on a daily schedule, making it a constant process for men, unlike the cyclical fertility of women.
The Importance of Consuming Vitamin A-Rich Foods ( 10:00 – 13:00 )
Lisa discusses the dietary sources of vitamin A, specifically highlighting animal foods such as liver, cod liver oil, and fatty animal products. She clarifies that while beta-carotene found in plant foods like carrots is often associated with vitamin A, it is the preformed vitamin A (retinol) found in animal-based foods that is crucial for spermatogenesis. The liver serves as the storage organ for vitamin A, and it is essential that men consume adequate amounts of these foods to maintain proper sperm health.
Animal Studies and Vitamin A Deficiency ( 13:00 – 17:00 )
The episode reviews animal studies showing the profound effects of vitamin A deficiency on sperm production. Lisa emphasizes how, in these studies, a lack of vitamin A led to the cessation of sperm production and a reduction in testicle size. When vitamin A was reintroduced into the diet, sperm production was restored. This highlights the essential, reversible nature of vitamin A’s impact on male fertility, stressing its importance for sperm health.
Research on Male Fertility Conditions ( 17:00 – 20:00 )
Lisa explores the link between vitamin A and various male fertility conditions. Specifically, she discusses cryptorchidism, a condition where one or both testicles fail to descend properly at birth, and how a deficiency in retinoic acid correlates with lower sperm production in these cases. The episode also highlights studies on varicocele, a condition affecting sperm quality, and the potential role of vitamin A in alleviating oxidative stress in sperm cells to improve fertility outcomes.
Vitamin A and Sperm Quality ( 20:00 – 22:00 )
This section covers research that shows the positive effects of vitamin A on sperm quality. Studies have demonstrated that men who consume vitamin A-rich foods like liver have higher sperm count, concentration, and motility compared to those who do not consume these foods. Lisa discusses how these findings provide valuable insights for improving sperm parameters in men who may be facing fertility challenges.
Retinoic Acid and Its Connection to Contraception ( 22:00 – 25:00 )
Lisa delves into the exploration of retinoic acid as a potential male contraceptive. Given its direct effect on sperm production, researchers have considered depriving men of vitamin A to suppress sperm production as a contraceptive method. Lisa explains how this idea fits into the broader context of fertility control and highlights the need for further research in this area.
Final Thoughts & Recommendations ( 25:00 – 27:00 )
Lisa concludes the episode by summarizing the critical importance of vitamin A for sperm production and male fertility. She emphasizes the need for men to consider incorporating vitamin A-rich foods, like liver, into their diets to support reproductive health. She also suggests that couples trying to conceive should be aware of the role of nutrition, especially vitamin A, in male fertility and considers the benefits of nutrient-based approaches over supplementation.
TRANSCRIPT
+

title: The Period Brain: Understanding Progesterone and Its Impact on Women’s Health | Ep. 593
main_text:
Podcast Host:
Dr. Hill is an award-winning researcher, professor, and author of This Is Your Brain on Birth Control, which changed the national conversation about women’s hormones and the birth control pill. Her new book,
Audio Player
00:00
00:00
Use Up/Down Arrow keys to increase or decrease volume.
Podcast: Play in new window | Download | Embed
Subscribe: Apple Podcasts | RSS
Episode Overview:
In this episode of the Fertility Friday Podcast, Lisa interviews Dr. Sarah Hill about her new book, The Period Brain. They explore the fascinating science behind progesterone, its effects on women’s health, and how research on women’s hormones is often misunderstood. Dr. Hill explains how the lack of accurate research on women’s health, particularly the under-representation of women in scientific studies, has led to misconceptions about female physiology. The conversation highlights the psychological and physical changes women experience in the second half of their cycle and how societal pressures often contribute to the misunderstanding of women’s hormonal realities.
Key Topics Covered:
The importance of progesterone in the second half of the menstrual cycle
How menstrual cycle research has historically excluded women
The science behind PMS and hormonal fluctuations in women
Why progesterone is often overlooked despite its crucial role in health
The consequences of minimal research on women’s hormonal health
How hormonal shifts during the cycle affect women’s mental, physical, and emotional states
The need for more comprehensive studies on women’s health, especially in drug trials and treatment efficacy
Listener Takeaways:
Progesterone plays a crucial role in both physical and psychological aspects of women’s health, but is often overlooked in research.
Women’s hormonal fluctuations impact everything from mood and behavior to the efficacy of medications.
Research on women’s health has been largely based on male-centric models, leading to an incomplete understanding of female physiology.
Understanding the menstrual cycle and tracking hormonal changes can empower women to make informed decisions about their health.
The hormonal shifts in women’s cycles require tailored healthcare approaches that account for these changes.
Key Moments (Timestamps & Detailed Summaries)
Episode Introduction & Dr. Sarah Hill’s Background ( 00:00 – 05:00 )
Lisa introduces Dr. Sarah Hill, an award-winning researcher and author of This Is Your Brain on Birth Control and her new book The Period Brain. They discuss the overarching themes of the episode: the under-representation of women in scientific research and how hormonal fluctuations, particularly progesterone, affect women’s health. Dr. Hill highlights how the research on female hormones is lacking, which has led to widespread misconceptions about women’s health.
The Dark Half of the Menstrual Cycle ( 05:00 – 10:00 )
Dr. Hill explains how the second half of the menstrual cycle (the luteal phase) is often ignored in discussions about women’s health. She dives into the role of progesterone and how its influence is not well understood in both the scientific community and the general public. Lisa and Dr. Hill discuss how the lack of awareness about progesterone contributes to the confusion and distress that women experience during this phase of the cycle.
Why Progesterone Is Overlooked ( 10:00 – 15:00 )
Dr. Hill shares her research on the importance of progesterone in the luteal phase. She highlights how research often focuses on estrogen, leaving progesterone in the background. The conversation covers how the medical community and mainstream discussions about women’s hormones typically leave out progesterone, which plays a significant role in everything from mood regulation to bone health.
PMS and Its Connection to Progesterone ( 15:00 – 20:00 )
The conversation shifts to the emotional and physical symptoms women experience during PMS. Dr. Hill explains that PMS is not a biological defect but a predictable response to hormonal fluctuations, particularly progesterone. She argues that understanding what is happening in the body during the luteal phase can help women better manage the symptoms associated with PMS.
The Problem with One-Size-Fits-All Research ( 20:00 – 25:00 )
Dr. Hill discusses how research on women’s health has historically been designed around male models. She explains that until recently, most research studies only included men or studied women during a narrow window of their cycle, typically the follicular phase when estrogen is dominant. This approach has resulted in a lack of understanding about how women’s bodies respond to medications and interventions across the entire cycle.
The Importance of Sex Differentiation in Research ( 25:00 – 30:00 )
Dr. Hill addresses the need for more research focused on sex differentiation. She explains that male and female bodies are different and that these differences should be considered when designing scientific studies. Dr. Hill advocates for including women in studies at different points of their cycle and ensuring that the impacts of hormonal fluctuations are accounted for in medical research.
How Hormonal Fluctuations Affect Women’s Health ( 30:00 – 35:00 )
Dr. Hill delves deeper into how hormonal changes impact women’s mental and physical health. She discusses how progesterone influences the brain and body, including changes in mood, motivation, and sleep during the luteal phase. Dr. Hill emphasizes that women’s health is often misunderstood because our bodies operate on cyclical hormonal rhythms, unlike the more consistent hormone levels in men.
Addressing the Cycle’s Impact on Chronic Health Conditions ( 35:00 – 40:00 )
The conversation moves to the intersection of women’s hormonal cycles and chronic health conditions like asthma, ADHD, and autoimmune diseases. Dr. Hill explains how symptoms of these conditions can change during different phases of the menstrual cycle. For example, many women experience worsening asthma symptoms during the luteal phase. Understanding this can help women receive more tailored care during these times.
The Role of Progesterone in Autoimmune Diseases ( 40:00 – 45:00 )
Dr. Hill explores the relationship between progesterone and autoimmune diseases. She discusses the concept of the “pregnancy prevention hypothesis,” which suggests that the high rates of autoimmune diseases in women today could be related to the fact that women are no longer pregnant as frequently as in the past. This loss of progesterone’s anti-inflammatory effects could be contributing to increased autoimmunity.
The Need for Comprehensive Research on Women’s Health ( 45:00 – 50:00 )
Dr. Hill calls for a complete overhaul of how women’s health is studied. She stresses the importance of including women in research and accounting for the different hormonal phases of their cycles. She also advocates for more accurate representation of female physiology in medical treatments, particularly in drug trials, where women’s hormonal fluctuations are often ignored.
Building Resilience to Hormonal Changes ( 50:00 – 55:00 )
Dr. Hill shares practical advice for women to build resilience to hormonal changes. She talks about the importance of healthy lifestyle choices, including eating well, managing stress, and getting enough sleep. These factors help women adapt to hormonal shifts, making the changes less disruptive and more manageable.
Final Thoughts & Recommendations ( 55:00 – 58:00 )
Lisa and Dr. Hill wrap up the conversation by emphasizing the importance of understanding your own cycle and tracking your symptoms. Dr. Hill encourages women to educate themselves about their hormonal changes and seek out resources like The Period Brain to better understand what their bodies are going through. She ends with a call to action for women to trust their bodies and embrace their hormonal cycles.

title: Misinformation on TikTok: Contraceptive Myths & Social Media Impact | Ep. 592
main_text:
Podcast Host:
Lisa Hendrickson is a certified fertility awareness educator and holistic reproductive health practitioner with over 20 years of experience. As the host of the Fertility Friday Podcast and author of The Fifth Vital Sign, Lisa helps women and practitioners understand the menstrual cycle as a powerful diagnostic tool for fertility, hormone health, and overall well-being.
Audio Player
00:00
00:00
Use Up/Down Arrow keys to increase or decrease volume.
Podcast: Play in new window | Download | Embed
Subscribe: Apple Podcasts | RSS
Episode Overview:
In Episode 592 of the Fertility Friday Podcast, Lisa Hendrickson-Jack explores the growing influence of social media platforms, particularly TikTok, on contraceptive decision-making. Drawing from a study that examines the spread of contraceptive misinformation online, Lisa addresses the rise of alternative birth control methods, such as fertility awareness-based methods (FABMs), and the reasons why TikTok has become a major source of information for young adults. The episode discusses the complexities of medical information in the age of short-form video and social media, emphasizing the challenges health professionals face in navigating these platforms.
Key Topics Covered
TikTok’s impact on contraceptive knowledge and user behavior
Misinformation on social media and its potential consequences
The increasing popularity of non-hormonal birth control methods
Fertility awareness-based methods (FABMs) and their portrayal online
The limitations of short-form medical content
Why the medical community must adapt to changing patient information-seeking behaviors
Listener Takeaways:
Social media platforms like TikTok are reshaping the way young adults access information about contraceptives.
Misinformation is prevalent on TikTok, particularly concerning hormonal contraception and non-hormonal methods like fertility awareness.
TikTok serves as a voice for many women who feel unheard or dismissed by healthcare professionals, particularly in relation to their contraceptive choices.
As a women’s health professional, it’s important to engage with social media and understand the impact it has on patients’ health decisions.
Accurate, evidence-based content is essential in providing a counterbalance to misinformation.
Key Moments (Timestamps & Detailed Summaries)
Introduction to Misinformation on TikTok ( 00:00 – 04:00 )
Lisa introduces the episode and highlights the growing concern about misinformation on TikTok regarding birth control choices. She discusses how TikTok is influencing women’s health decisions, particularly for younger audiences. The episode sets the stage for a deeper dive into the research on contraceptive misinformation in the social media age.
TikTok’s Algorithm and Its Impact on User Behavior ( 04:00 – 08:00 )
The conversation shifts to how TikTok’s algorithm works, showing users more of what they engage with. Lisa explains how this can lead to creating a “bubble” where users are constantly exposed to content that reinforces their views, potentially distorting their perception of contraceptive options. She stresses the need for awareness of how algorithms shape content exposure.
The Definition of Misinformation in Social Media Studies ( 08:00 – 12:00 )
Lisa critiques the study’s definition of misinformation, pointing out how it often focuses on content that contradicts the consensus of the medical establishment, rather than evaluating the actual accuracy of the information. She discusses the challenges of categorizing information as “misleading” and how this can oversimplify complex health topics like contraception.
The Rise of Fertility Awareness-Based Methods (FABMs) ( 12:00 – 16:00 )
Lisa discusses the increasing popularity of fertility awareness-based methods (FABMs) and how TikTok influencers promote these methods. She highlights how the research paper acknowledges that FABMs can be effective when used correctly, but points out their dismissal as ineffective without proper education and guidance.
Fertility Awareness Methods vs. Hormonal Birth Control ( 16:00 – 20:00 )
The episode covers the dichotomy between natural contraceptive methods and hormonal birth control. Lisa reflects on the study’s findings, which suggest that TikTok videos discussing FABMs are often deemed misleading, yet there is evidence supporting the effectiveness of these methods. She discusses the nuances of how these methods are presented online and the importance of proper education.
The Inherent Limitations of Short-Form Medical Content ( 20:00 – 24:00 )
Lisa emphasizes the limitations of social media in delivering complex medical information. She critiques the study’s methodology, highlighting that short-form videos, such as those on TikTok, cannot provide the full context necessary for making informed health decisions. The importance of seeing social media content as an introduction to deeper research is discussed.
Social Media’s Role in Reshaping Patient-Provider Relationships ( 24:00 – 28:00 )
Lisa examines how social media is changing the dynamic between patients and healthcare providers. The paper discusses the growing trend of patients seeking out health information on TikTok due to dissatisfaction with the care they receive in medical settings. Lisa explains how this shift is affecting how women trust and interact with medical professionals.
Distrust of Hormonal Contraception ( 28:00 – 32:00 )
Lisa explores the growing distrust of hormonal contraception, particularly in light of personal experiences shared on TikTok. She reflects on the study’s findings that many women who feel unheard by their healthcare providers are turning to alternative sources of information, like social media, to find answers.
The Need for Open Dialogue in Healthcare ( 32:00 – 36:00 )
Lisa highlights the importance of open dialogue between patients and healthcare providers. She discusses how the medical community must address the concerns raised by patients, particularly when it comes to the side effects of hormonal contraception. Lisa argues that medical professionals need to create a more inclusive and collaborative environment for contraceptive counseling.
Acknowledging Patient Concerns in Social Media ( 36:00 – 40:00 )
The discussion turns to the paper’s conclusion that healthcare providers must acknowledge the role social media plays in shaping women’s views on contraceptive methods. Lisa shares a quote from the study, which recognizes that women are turning to social media because they feel dismissed or coerced by medical professionals.
The Growing Demand for Non-Hormonal Birth Control ( 40:00 – 44:00 )
Lisa reflects on the increasing demand for non-hormonal birth control methods. She highlights the importance of providing evidence-based information about fertility awareness and other alternatives to hormonal contraception. The episode emphasizes the need for healthcare providers to adapt to the changing needs and preferences of their patients.
Conclusions & Moving Forward ( 44:00 – 48:00 )
In the final segment, Lisa summarizes the study’s findings and its implications for both healthcare providers and patients. She stresses that while misinformation on TikTok is a concern, there is a growing demand for accurate, evidence-based information. Lisa encourages women’s health professionals to engage with social media, provide balanced content, and offer a clear, informed perspective on reproductive health.
TRANSCRIPT
+

title: IUD Insertion Pain: New Guidelines for Pain Management | Ep. 591
main_text:
Podcast Host:
Lisa Hendrickson is a certified fertility awareness educator and holistic reproductive health practitioner with over 20 years of experience. As the host of the Fertility Friday Podcast and author of The Fifth Vital Sign, Lisa helps women and practitioners understand the menstrual cycle as a powerful diagnostic tool for fertility, hormone health, and overall well-being.
Audio Player
00:00
00:00
Use Up/Down Arrow keys to increase or decrease volume.
Podcast: Play in new window | Download | Embed
Subscribe: Apple Podcasts | RSS
Episode Overview:
In Episode 591 of the Fertility Friday Podcast, Lisa Hendrickson-Jack addresses the often-overlooked issue of pain during IUD insertion. She explores a new 2025 consensus statement from the American College of Obstetrics and Gynecology (ACOG), which acknowledges the real pain that many women experience during this procedure. The episode discusses the inadequacy of current pain management practices and highlights the importance of healthcare professionals understanding and addressing pain management for women undergoing gynecological procedures. Lisa also provides a fertility awareness perspective on the timing of IUD insertion and practical considerations for women undergoing this procedure.
Key Topics Covered:
The prevalence of pain during IUD insertion and the importance of pain management
ACOG’s new consensus statement on pain management for cervical procedures
Understanding the cervical anatomy and its impact on IUD insertion pain
Why common pain management strategies, like NSAIDs, may be ineffective for IUD insertion
The role of local anesthetics (lidocaine) in effective pain relief
How medical professionals should approach pain management for individual patients
Listener Takeaways:
Pain during IUD insertion is real, common, and often underestimated by healthcare professionals.
ACOG’s new guidelines recommend local anesthetics like lidocaine for effective pain relief during IUD insertion.
The lack of pain management during this procedure reflects broader issues of dismissing women’s pain in medical settings.
Women should advocate for their own pain management options during procedures, including IUD insertion.
The importance of considering cervical position and timing of insertion from a fertility awareness perspective.
Key Moments (Timestamps & Detailed Summaries)
Introduction to IUD Insertion Pain ( 00:00 – 04:00 )
Lisa introduces the topic of IUD insertion pain and the ongoing issues with pain management during this procedure. She highlights the recent surge in women sharing their experiences of intense pain during IUD insertion.
ACOG’s Consensus Statement on Pain Management( 04:00 – 08:00 )
Lisa presents the key findings from the new ACOG consensus statement released in July 2025, which acknowledges the real and varied pain experiences that women have during procedures like IUD insertion. She discusses the statement’s recommendation for more comprehensive pain management strategies.
Medical Professionals’ Misunderstanding of Pain ( 08:00 – 12:00 )
Lisa addresses the issue of many healthcare providers underestimating the pain women experience during IUD insertion. She emphasizes how biases, such as systemic racism and dismissive attitudes toward women’s pain, contribute to a lack of appropriate pain relief options.
The Definition of Pain in Medical Contexts ( 12:00 – 16:00 )
The episode dives into how pain is defined in the context of medical procedures, highlighting that pain is a highly subjective experience, and acknowledging that women’s pain during IUD insertion is often ignored or minimized.
Why IUD Insertion Pain is Often Ignored ( 16:00 – 20:00 )
Lisa explains the problem with healthcare providers not offering pain relief for IUD insertion, despite evidence showing that many women experience severe pain. She critiques the common approach of prescribing NSAIDs and highlights the inadequacy of this method.
Effective Pain Management: Lidocaine ( 20:00 – 24:00 )
Lisa shares the findings from the consensus statement, which recommends the use of lidocaine as a local anesthetic to reduce pain during IUD insertion. She explains how this method is more effective than other options, like cervical ripening agents.
The Fertility Awareness Perspective on Cervical Anatomy ( 24:00 – 28:00 )
From a fertility awareness standpoint, Lisa talks about how the cervix behaves during different phases of the menstrual cycle. She suggests that the best time to get an IUD inserted might be during the fertile window, when the cervix is naturally softer and more open, potentially making the procedure less painful.
Addressing Bias in Pain Management ( 28:00 – 32:00 )
Lisa highlights how certain populations, such as women with a history of pelvic pain, abuse, or chronic conditions, may experience more pain during IUD insertion. She emphasizes the importance of healthcare providers being sensitive to these factors and offering pain management options for everyone.
The Role of Self-Advocacy in Pain Management ( 32:00 – 36:00 )
The conversation shifts to the importance of women advocating for themselves when it comes to pain management. Lisa provides practical tips for women to request pain relief options and ensures that they are taken seriously by medical professionals.
Recommendations for Healthcare Providers ( 36:00 – 38:00 )
Lisa concludes the episode by reviewing the recommendations for healthcare providers from the consensus statement, urging them to listen to their patients, offer appropriate pain management options, and stop assuming that all women experience pain in the same way.

title: Oral Health and Fertility: Exploring the Connection with Dr. Katie Lee | Ep. 590
main_text:
Podcast Host:
Lisa Hendrickson is a certified fertility awareness educator and holistic reproductive health practitioner with over 20 years of experience. As the host of the Fertility Friday Podcast and author of The Fifth Vital Sign, Lisa helps women and practitioners understand the menstrual cycle as a powerful diagnostic tool for fertility, hormone health, and overall well-being.
Audio Player
00:00
00:00
Use Up/Down Arrow keys to increase or decrease volume.

Episode Overview:
In Episode 590 of the Fertility Friday Podcast, Lisa Hendrickson-Jack explores the connection between oral health and fertility with Dr. Katie Lee, a functional dentist and author. Dr. Lee shares her personal story of overcoming a traumatic ATV accident that led her to dentistry and an understanding of the impact oral health has on systemic health, particularly fertility. Dr. Lee discusses the role of oral bacteria and how imbalances in the mouth can affect both male and female fertility. The episode also delves into practical strategies to maintain oral health, such as salivary testing and the role of diet, and emphasizes the importance of looking beyond traditional reproductive health practices.
Key Topics Covered:
The connection between oral health and fertility
How bacteria in the mouth can affect systemic health and fertility
Dr. Katie Lee’s personal journey and the impact of her experience on her approach to oral health
The importance of salivary testing and understanding oral microbiome imbalances
Practical strategies to support oral health and its impact on fertility
The role of diet, stress, and lifestyle in maintaining oral and reproductive health
Listener Takeaways:
Oral health plays a crucial role in overall health and fertility.
Specific strains of bacteria in the mouth can contribute to fertility challenges.
Salivary testing can uncover underlying issues in the oral microbiome that may affect fertility.
Regular brushing, flossing, and diet are vital for maintaining healthy oral microbiome.
Fertility issues may benefit from considering oral health, especially in unexplained infertility cases.
Key Moments (Timestamps & Detailed Summaries)
Introduction to the Topic ( 00:00 – 04:00 )
Lisa introduces Dr. Katie Lee and the focus of today’s episode on oral health’s connection to fertility. Dr. Lee shares her background and how her personal health challenges led her to explore this connection.
Dr. Katie Lee’s Story and the Importance of Oral Health ( 03:30 – 07:30 )
Dr. Lee discusses her traumatic ATV accident as a teenager and how it shaped her understanding of how oral health impacts the entire body. She reflects on how this experience sparked her passion for dentistry.
The Link Between Oral Health and Systemic Health( 07:30 – 15:00 )
Dr. Lee explains how oral health issues can lead to systemic conditions like heart disease, diabetes, and fertility problems. She shares the story of a couple who struggled with infertility, where oral bacteria were a key factor.
The Role of Salivary Testing in Oral Health ( 15:00 – 20:30 )
The conversation shifts to the importance of salivary testing to detect harmful bacteria that may affect fertility. Dr. Lee emphasizes how testing can reveal hidden issues, even in the absence of symptoms.
How Oral Bacteria Affect Fertility ( 20:30 – 25:30 )
Dr. Lee elaborates on the connection between oral bacteria, leaky gums, and fertility. She explains how bacteria can enter the bloodstream and target the reproductive systems, potentially impairing fertility.
Preventing and Managing Oral Health Issues ( 25:30 –30:00 )
Dr. Lee discusses prevention strategies for maintaining oral health, including proper brushing, flossing, and the use of oral probiotics. She also talks about the impact of diet and lifestyle choices on the oral microbiome.
Airway Health and Fertility ( 30:00 – 35:00 )
Lisa and Dr. Lee discuss how airway health, including nasal breathing and the prevention of sleep apnea, plays a role in fertility. Dr. Lee stresses the importance of diagnosing and addressing airway issues, which can impact overall health and fertility.
Root Canals and Their Impact on Fertility ( 35:00 – 40:00 )
The conversation turns to the controversial topic of root canals. Dr. Lee provides a balanced view on the pros and cons of root canals, emphasizing the importance of monitoring for infection and ensuring proper treatment.
The Role of Nutrition in Oral Health ( 40:00 – 45:00 )
Dr. Lee explains how nutrition, particularly the balance of plant-based and animal-based foods, supports oral health. She shares her recommendations for supplements that promote oral and systemic health.
Identifying Oral Health Issues Early ( 45:00 – 50:30 )
Dr. Lee talks about signs that indicate oral health issues may be affecting fertility, including bad breath, bleeding gums, and frequent cavities. She emphasizes the need for testing to uncover potential bacterial imbalances.
Recommendations for Finding the Right Dentist ( 50:30 – 57:00 )
Dr. Lee offers advice on finding a dentist who practices holistic or functional dentistry and provides resources for locating dentists who offer salivary testing. She also shares information about her own practice and telehealth options.

Does Oral Health Impact Fertility? | Dr. Katie Lee
Discover how oral health impacts fertility in this groundbreaking conversation with functional dentist Dr. Katie Lee. Learn the surprising link between the oral microbiome, systemic inflammation, and reproductive health.
For the first time on the podcast, Lisa explores the connection between oral health and fertility with Dr. Katie Lee — functional dentist, author of Saved by the Mouth, and founder of the Collective Health Society. This interview challenges conventional thinking by unpacking how specific oral bacteria can influence reproductive outcomes, including unexplained infertility, PCOS, and endometriosis.
Dr. Lee discusses how oral infections and dysbiosis can contribute to systemic inflammation and disrupt hormonal balance. She also explains the importance of salivary testing, airway health, and nutrient status — revealing key insights for practitioners supporting clients with fertility challenges.
Timestamps
00:00 – Introducing Dr. Katie Lee & her origin story
08:40 – The accident that inspired her career in dentistry
15:30 – How oral infections can impact fertility outcomes
21:45 – Salivary testing and its role in diagnosis
27:50 – The oral microbiome and systemic inflammation
34:00 – Airway health and its role in reproduction
43:15 – Root canals, implants & long-term oral health
51:20 – The link between oral bacteria and endometriosis, PCOS, BV
01:01:45 – Best practices for optimizing oral health
01:10:00 – Finding a functionally trained dentist
Key Takeaways
The oral microbiome is the second largest in the body and plays a critical role in systemic inflammation and fertility outcomes.
Specific oral pathogens such as *Fusobacterium nucleatum* and *Porphyromonas gingivalis* have been associated with infertility, endometriosis, and PCOS.
Oral health and fertility are interconnected — pathogens can enter the bloodstream through the gums and target reproductive tissues.
Salivary testing is an underutilized diagnostic tool for identifying hidden infections that may contribute to unexplained infertility.
Practitioners should consider airway testing and oral microbiome health in clients with persistent reproductive concerns.

title: PMDD vs PMS: Hormonal Influence on Cognitive Function | Ep. 589
main_text:
Podcast Host:
Lisa Hendrickson is a certified fertility awareness educator and holistic reproductive health practitioner with over 20 years of experience. As the host of the Fertility Friday Podcast and author of The Fifth Vital Sign, Lisa helps women and practitioners understand the menstrual cycle as a powerful diagnostic tool for fertility, hormone health, and overall well-being.
Audio Player
00:00
00:00
Use Up/Down Arrow keys to increase or decrease volume.
Podcast: Play in new window | Download | Embed
Subscribe: Apple Podcasts | RSS
Episode Overview:
In Episode 589 of the Fertility Friday Podcast, Lisa Hendrickson-Jack dives into the topic of Premenstrual Dysphoric Disorder (PMDD), reviewing a research study on mood changes, cognitive performance, and appetite fluctuations throughout different phases of the menstrual cycle. The study focuses on comparing women with PMDD to those without, and how they experience hormonal fluctuations, symptoms of depression, anxiety, and memory loss. Lisa critiques the study’s methodology, particularly how the researchers dismissed hormonal fluctuations and focused on a psychiatric approach. She highlights the importance of a comprehensive hormonal understanding in treating PMDD and PMS symptoms, emphasizing the need for menstrual cycle-based research.
Key Topics Covered:
Understanding the difference between PMDD and PMS
Cognitive performance and mood changes in PMDD
The study’s methodology: testing hormones and comparing control groups
The hormonal role in PMDD and the limitations of single hormone testing
The impact of food cravings and appetite changes in PMDD
Critique of research methodology and its implications on treatment approaches
Listener Takeaways:
PMDD is an exacerbated version of PMS, severely impacting daily life.
Research often overlooks the cyclical nature of hormones in PMDD.
Hormonal testing needs to be done across the entire luteal phase, not just spot tests.
Lifestyle interventions and tracking menstrual cycles can offer insights into PMDD.
There’s a need for more thorough research into the hormonal aspect of PMDD.
Key Moments (Timestamps & Detailed Summaries)
Introduction to PMDD Study ( 00:00 – 03:30 )
Lisa introduces the topic of PMDD and sets the stage for the episode. She explains how PMDD is a severe form of PMS, defining it as debilitating rather than just inconvenient, and previews the discussion around a research study comparing mood, cognitive performance, and appetite in women with and without PMDD.
The Definition of PMDD and PMS ( 03:30 – 07:00 )
Lisa clarifies the difference between PMDD and PMS, focusing on how PMDD is defined by significant mood changes, irritability, fatigue, and cognitive impairment that interfere with daily functioning. She also discusses the typical timing of PMDD symptoms, appearing in the luteal phase, specifically the week before menstruation, and disappearing afterward.
Study Overview: Hormonal and Cognitive Changes in PMDD ( 07:00 – 10:30 )
Lisa reviews the research study titled “Changes in Mood, Cognitive Performance, and Appetite in Women with PMDD”. The study explored the psychological and cognitive changes in women with PMDD versus control women. Researchers looked at hormone levels, mood changes, cognitive performance, and food cravings during the luteal and follicular phases.
Researchers’ Methodology and Its Limitations ( 10:30 – 14:00 )
Lisa critiques the study’s methodology, particularly the way hormones were tested. The researchers conducted spot hormone tests once during each phase of the cycle, without tracking how hormones fluctuated throughout the cycle. Lisa emphasizes that this is a major flaw in the study, especially when trying to understand a condition like PMDD, which is cyclical.
Cognitive Function and Mood Fluctuations in PMDD ( 14:00 – 18:00 )
The study found that women with PMDD showed significantly worse mood, cognitive performance, and appetite fluctuations compared to both their follicular phase and to control participants without PMDD. Memory tasks and word recall were notably worse for those with PMDD. Lisa highlights these findings, noting that the cognitive and emotional struggles are severe during the luteal phase.
Appetite Changes and Food Cravings in PMDD ( 18:00 – 22:00 )
Lisa discusses the findings related to appetite. Women with PMDD were shown to consume about 100 more calories, primarily from fat and protein, during lunch. These findings align with the food cravings that often accompany PMDD. Lisa emphasizes the need for understanding the physical basis behind these cravings and how they may relate to hormonal fluctuations.
The Role of Hormones in PMDD ( 22:00 – 25:00 )
Lisa goes into more depth about the hormone testing conducted in the study. Despite the symptoms consistently being linked to the luteal phase, the study found no significant difference in estradiol or progesterone levels between the two groups. Lisa critiques the study’s conclusion that there is no hormonal component to PMDD, questioning how this could be deduced from such limited testing.
Critique: One-Time Hormone Testing Is Insufficient ( 25:00 – 28:00 )
Lisa continues to discuss how the study’s single spot hormone test failed to capture the dynamic hormonal changes throughout the luteal phase. She calls for a more thorough hormonal analysis that would involve testing progesterone regularly throughout the luteal phase, not just once. This would give a clearer picture of the hormonal patterns that could be involved in PMDD.
The Psychiatric Approach to Treating PMDD ( 28:00 – 33:00 )
The study suggested that psychiatric medication (like SSRIs) could be the treatment for PMDD due to the absence of clear hormonal changes. Lisa critiques this approach, pointing out how psychiatric medications are often prescribed without considering hormonal contributions to mood and cognitive changes. She calls for a more integrative approach that considers both hormonal and psychiatric factors in treating PMDD.
The Need for Menstrual Cycle-Based Research ( 33:00 – 37:00 )
Lisa emphasizes the importance of conducting research that accounts for menstrual cycle fluctuations. She advocates for more research on how progesterone and estrogen change throughout the cycle and affect symptoms, especially in PMDD. By using a more nuanced approach, including tools like temperature tracking and mucus observation, researchers could gain a better understanding of the hormonal dynamics at play.
The Implications for Women’s Health and Treatment ( 37:00 – 40:00 )
Lisa discusses the broader implications of this flawed research for women’s health. She stresses the need for a new perspective, one that takes the menstrual cycle seriously and investigates the hormonal changes that occur throughout the cycle. Without this, women are at risk of being misdiagnosed or treated with medications that don’t address the root cause of their symptoms.
Why Menstrual Cycle Awareness Matters ( 40:00 – 45:00 )
Lisa ties the discussion back to the importance of menstrual cycle tracking. She explains how fertility awareness and understanding one’s cycle can help identify hormonal imbalances and pinpoint when issues like PMDD or PMS occur. Women can learn more about their bodies and how to work with their natural cycles for better health and well-being.
The Potential for Bioidentical Hormones and Lifestyle Changes ( 45:00 – 50:00 )
Lisa presents the potential of using bioidentical progesterone to help women who have hormonal imbalances contributing to PMDD. She contrasts this natural approach with psychiatric medications and highlights how lifestyle changes (including diet, exercise, and sleep) can improve symptoms and balance hormones.
Closing Thoughts and Future Research ( 50:00 – 57:00 )
Lisa wraps up by highlighting the limitations of current research on PMDD and its impact on treatment. She urges a more holistic approach to studying and treating PMDD, emphasizing the need for better scientific methods that consider the full complexity of women’s hormonal health. She encourages listeners to continue to question conventional research and advocate for more comprehensive studies.
TRANSCRIPT
+

title: The Menstrual Cycle as an Overlooked Vital Sign in Psychiatry | Ep. 588
main_text:
Podcast Host:
Lisa Hendrickson is a certified fertility awareness educator and holistic reproductive health practitioner with over 20 years of experience. As the host of the Fertility Friday Podcast and author of The Fifth Vital Sign, Lisa helps women and practitioners understand the menstrual cycle as a powerful diagnostic tool for fertility, hormone health, and overall well-being.
Audio Player
00:00
00:00
Use Up/Down Arrow keys to increase or decrease volume.
Podcast: Play in new window | Download | Embed
Subscribe: Apple Podcasts | RSS
Episode Overview:
In Episode 588 of the Fertility Friday Podcast, Lisa Hendrickson-Jack is joined by Dr. Katie Marwick, a psychiatrist and researcher based in Edinburgh, UK. Together, they explore why the menstrual cycle should be considered a vital sign in psychiatry and how ignoring cyclical hormonal patterns has led to gaps in diagnosis, treatment, and patient care.
Dr. Marwick shares insights from her research paper, “The Menstrual Cycle as an Overlooked Vital Sign in Psychiatry,” highlighting how a wide range of psychiatric conditions—including depression, anxiety, psychosis, eating disorders, and bipolar disorder—can worsen predictably at specific phases of the menstrual cycle. The conversation challenges long-standing assumptions in psychiatric training, discusses the limitations of current treatment models, and emphasizes how simply asking about the menstrual cycle could dramatically improve outcomes for women.
Key Topics Covered:
Why the menstrual cycle qualifies as a psychiatric vital sign
The difference between PMDD and premenstrual exacerbation
Psychiatric conditions are shown to worsen premenstrually
Gaps in medical and psychiatric training around menstruation
Hormonal stabilization vs. psychiatric medication approaches
How cycle awareness can reduce hospitalizations and crises
The power of symptom tracking and anticipatory care planning
Listener Takeaways:
Many psychiatric symptoms worsen predictably at specific cycle phases.
Premenstrual symptom worsening extends far beyond PMDD.
Asking about the menstrual cycle can unlock critical diagnostic insight.
Hormonal treatments may complement psychiatric care in some cases.
Understanding cyclical patterns can be deeply empowering for patients.
Psychiatry has historically overlooked female physiology in care models.
Key Moments (Timestamps & Detailed Summaries)
Introducing the Menstrual Cycle as a Psychiatric Vital Sign ( 00:00 – 03:30 )
Lisa introduces the episode’s central theme: why the menstrual cycle should be considered a vital sign in psychiatric care. She previews the research paper that inspired the discussion and introduces Dr. Katie Marwick.
Dr. Katie Marwick’s Background & Research Focus ( 03:30 – 07:00 )
Dr. Marwick shares her work as a reproductive psychiatrist in Edinburgh and explains how working with women during reproductive transitions led her to question psychiatry’s lack of focus on menstrual cycles.
Gaps in Psychiatric Training ( 07:00 – 11:00 )
Dr. Marwick explains how menstruation, PMS, PMDD, and menopause are largely absent from psychiatric education. She notes that clinicians often don’t ask about cycles simply because they were never trained to consider them.
PMDD vs. Premenstrual Exacerbation ( 11:00 – 16:00 )
The conversation clarifies the distinction between PMDD and premenstrual exacerbation, where existing psychiatric conditions worsen cyclically. Dr. Marwick explains why this distinction is essential for accurate diagnosis and treatment.
Psychiatric Conditions Linked to the Menstrual Cycle ( 16:00 – 21:00 )
Dr. Marwick outlines psychiatric conditions shown to worsen premenstrually, including depression, panic disorder, eating disorders, substance use disorders, borderline personality disorder, psychosis, and bipolar disorder.
Evidence Supporting Cycle-Based Symptom Tracking ( 21:00 – 25:30 )
Dr. Marwick discusses research using prospectively recorded symptom data, showing strong evidence that psychiatric symptoms fluctuate in relation to menstrual cycle phases.
Why Patients Often Don’t Make the Connection ( 25:30 – 30:00 )
Lisa and Dr. Marwick explore why many women fail to recognize cyclical symptom patterns, citing cultural silence, lack of education, and coping mechanisms that prioritize survival over reflection.
Stigma, Assumptions, and Avoidance in Psychiatry ( 30:00 – 35:00 )
Dr. Marwick explains how discomfort, fear of invalidation, and historical misogyny contribute to psychiatry’s avoidance of menstrual health discussions.
Treatment Models: SSRIs vs. Hormonal Approaches ( 35:00 – 39:30 )
The discussion compares traditional psychiatric medication approaches with hormonal stabilization strategies, including ovulation suppression and hormone-based interventions.
Potential Benefits of Hormonal Stabilization ( 39:30 – 43:30 )
Dr. Marwick highlights research showing that addressing hormonal fluctuation—alongside standard psychiatric care—may significantly reduce hospital admissions, including up to a 50% reduction in psychotic disorders.
Empowerment Through Cycle Awareness ( 43:30 – 47:30 )
Lisa emphasizes how understanding cyclical symptom patterns helps patients anticipate difficult phases, build support plans, and reduce fear during symptom flare-ups.
Why Psychiatry Has Ignored the Menstrual Cycle ( 47:30 – 50:30 )
Dr. Marwick reflects on historical bias, male-centric medical models, and fears of oversimplifying women’s mental health by attributing symptoms to hormones.
Final Reflections & Core Message ( 50:30 – 52:00 )
The episode closes with a clear call to action: routinely ask whether mental health symptoms are linked to the menstrual cycle—and allow that question to guide more effective, compassionate care.
TRANSCRIPT
+

title: Clean Skincare, Hormones & Fertility: The Hidden Toxins In Your Skincare | Ep. 587
main_text:
Podcast Host:
Lisa Hendrickson is a certified fertility awareness educator and holistic reproductive health practitioner with over 20 years of experience. As the host of the Fertility Friday Podcast and author of The Fifth Vital Sign, Lisa helps women and practitioners understand the menstrual cycle as a powerful diagnostic tool for fertility, hormone health, and overall well-being.
Audio Player
00:00
00:00
Use Up/Down Arrow keys to increase or decrease volume.
Podcast: Play in new window | Download | Embed
Subscribe: Apple Podcasts | RSS
Episode Overview:
In Episode 587 of the Fertility Friday Podcast, Lisa Hendrickson-Jack is joined by Courtney Joy Getts, Holistic Aesthetician and Education Lead at Primally Pure. This episode is a practical follow-up to the previous discussion on toxin exposure, narrowing the focus to skincare, hormone health, and fertility.
Together, Lisa and Courtney explore how the skin—our largest organ—absorbs what we put on it, how common skincare ingredients disrupt hormones, and why “natural” labels often don’t mean non-toxic. Courtney shares her personal journey through acne, greenwashing in the beauty industry, nervous system regulation, and how skincare can be aligned with the menstrual cycle to better support hormonal balance, skin health, and overall well-being.
Key Topics Covered:
How skincare products contribute to overall toxic load
Greenwashing in the “natural” beauty industry
Endocrine-disrupting chemicals in common skincare
Why fragrance is one of the most harmful hidden ingredients
Stress, the nervous system, and inflammatory skin conditions
Aluminum deodorants, sweating, and detoxification
Cycle-syncing skincare across the menstrual cycle
The role of animal-based ingredients in skin barrier health
Listener Takeaways:
Your skin absorbs ingredients similarly to ingestion.
Many “natural” products still contain hormone disruptors.
Fragrance can hide hundreds of undisclosed chemicals.
Stress and nervous system dysregulation impact skin health.
Sweating is essential for detoxification and hormonal balance.
Skincare can be adjusted to support each cycle phase.
Gentle, nourishing approaches often outperform aggressive treatments.
Key Moments (Timestamps & Detailed Summaries)
Episode Framing: Toxins & Daily Exposure ( 00:00 – 05:30 )
Lisa sets the stage for a continued deep dive into toxins, focusing this episode on skincare and personal care products as one of the most overlooked sources of daily chemical exposure. The emphasis is on education and reduction rather than perfection.
Guest Introduction: Courtney Joy Getts ( 05:30 – 11:30 )
Courtney shares her background as a licensed esthetician and founder of Primally Pure, explaining how her early passion for skincare evolved into a holistic approach centered on whole-body health.
Acne, Healing & Rethinking Skincare ( 11:30 – 18:30 )
Courtney opens up about her personal acne journey and how real healing came not from harsher products, but from lifestyle shifts—nutrition, stress reduction, hormone balance, and ingredient awareness.
“Everything Is Skincare.” ( 18:30 – 24:30 )
kincare is reframed as an internal-external ecosystem. Gut health, detox pathways, hormones, stress, and nervous system regulation are positioned as foundational to skin health.
Stress, the Nervous System & Skin Aging ( 24:30 – 32:00 )
A deep look at how chronic stress drives inflammation, premature aging, and acne. Courtney explains parasympathetic healing, vagus nerve activation, and why calming the nervous system is a skin intervention.
Toxic Burden & Hormone Disruption ( 32:00 – 38:00 )
Discussion on cumulative chemical exposure from personal care products and how it can burden detox pathways, disrupt estrogen balance, and impact fertility and menstrual health.
Greenwashing & the Fragrance Issue ( 38:00 – 45:00 )
Courtney breaks down common greenwashing tactics and explains why the word “fragrance” is one of the most problematic skincare ingredients due to undisclosed chemical blends.
Deodorant, Aluminum & Lymphatic Health ( 45:00 – 52:00 )
Why is deodorant often the first product to swap? A discussion on aluminum-based antiperspirants, sweating as a detox pathway, and the importance of lymphatic flow.
Why Clean Products Work Differently ( 35:00 – 39:30 )
Courtney explains the realities of truly clean formulation—ingredient sourcing, regenerative practices, shelf life, and why switching to natural products often requires an adjustment period.
Cycle-Syncing Skincare ( 58:30 – 1:04:30 )
Practical guidance for aligning skincare with the menstrual cycle:
Menstrual: Deep hydration + facial massage
Follicular/Ovulatory: Gentle exfoliation + circulation support
Luteal: Lymphatic drainage + inflammation-calming care
Final Takeaways ( 1:04:30 – 1:05:00 )
Lisa wraps up with the core message: skin health is inseparable from hormone health, fertility, and nervous system regulation. Awareness, ingredient literacy, and sustainable changes matter more than perfection.
TRANSCRIPT
+

title: Environmental Toxins, Fertility, and Finding Balance with Laura Adler | Ep. 586
main_text:
Podcast Host:
Lisa Hendrickson-Jack is a Certified Fertility Awareness Educator and the author of The Fifth Vital Sign and Real Food for Fertility. She created the Fertility Awareness Mastery Mentorship (FAMM) to train practitioners to use the menstrual cycle as a vital sign in clinical care.
Download a free chapter of The Fifth Vital Sign
Download a free chapter of Real Food for Fertility
Learn about FAMM
Audio Player
00:00
00:00
Use Up/Down Arrow keys to increase or decrease volume.
Podcast: Play in new window | Download | Embed
Subscribe: Apple Podcasts | RSS
Episode Overview:
In Episode 586 of the Fertility Friday Podcast, Lisa Hendrickson-Jack is joined by environmental health educator and science communicator Laura Adler for an in-depth conversation about environmental toxins and their impact on fertility, hormones, and overall health.
This episode explores how chemical exposures affect the body, why total avoidance is unrealistic, and how education and exposure reduction create meaningful health improvements. Lisa and Laura discuss endocrine-disrupting chemicals, the role of personal responsibility versus systemic regulation, and how women and practitioners can approach toxin reduction without fear, perfectionism, or overwhelm.
Key Topics Covered:
What environmental toxins are and how daily exposure occurs
Personal responsibility vs. systemic chemical regulation
Endocrine-disrupting chemicals and fertility outcomes
Phthalates, bisphenols, and PFAS explained
Why “detox” is not the solution for most toxins
How exposure stacks and accumulates over time
Household dust as a major exposure source
Practical, accessible strategies to reduce toxic load
Balancing awareness without fear or obsession
Listener Takeaways:
Total toxin avoidance is impossible in the modern world.
Reduction, not perfection, is the most effective strategy.
Endocrine disruptors have strong links to fertility and hormone health.
Small, consistent changes significantly lower chronic exposure.
Stress and fear worsen health outcomes.
Behavior changes matter more than detox supplements.
Menstrual cycle charting can reflect improvements as exposure decreases.
Key Moments (Timestamps & Detailed Summaries)
Episode Introduction & Toxins Overview ( 00:00 – 06:00 )
Lisa introduces the topic of environmental toxins and frames the discussion around education, reduction, and realistic expectations rather than fear or perfection.
Meet Laura Adler & Her Background ( 06:00 – 13:00 )
Laura shares her journey into environmental health, how weight-loss resistance led her to chemical research, and why toxin exposure became central to her work.
What Are Environmental Toxins? ( 13:00 – 22:00 )
Laura explains what environmental chemicals are, how humans are exposed daily, and why the presence of chemicals in the body doesn’t automatically mean harm.
Chemicals, Safety & Scientific Uncertainty ( 22:00 – 31:00 )
The conversation explores how chemicals are studied, why human trials are limited, and how animal and epidemiological data inform safety decisions.
Manufacturing Doubt & Industry Influence ( 31:00 – 40:00 )
Laura explains how industries manufacture doubt, drawing parallels to tobacco, pesticides, and chemical regulation, and why this complicates public understanding.
Personal Control vs. Systemic Exposure ( 40:00 – 48:00 )
Lisa and Laura discuss the limits of individual action, acknowledging unavoidable exposures while reinforcing the value of personal reduction strategies.
Endocrine Disruptors & Fertility ( 48:00 – 58:00 )
Laura outlines the strongest evidence linking phthalates, bisphenols, and PFAS to fertility challenges, hormonal disruption, and reproductive outcomes.
Practical Reduction Strategies: Phthalates ( 58:00 – 1:07:00 )
The episode details where phthalates are found, including fragrances, plastics, and house dust, and how cleaning practices and fragrance reduction lower exposure.
Bisphenols, Plastics & Food Storage ( 1:07:00 – 1:16:00 )
Laura explains BPA and related compounds, exposure stacking, and why behavior changes like avoiding hot plastic and reducing canned foods matter.
PFAS: The Hardest Chemicals to Avoid( 1:16:00 – 1:24:00 )
The discussion covers PFAS sources, cookware, textiles, cosmetics, water filtration, and realistic expectations around unavoidable exposure.
Final Thoughts & Balanced Approach ( 1:24:00 – 1:28:00 )
Lisa and Laura emphasize stress reduction, long-term perspective, and the importance of focusing on meaningful changes rather than fear-based decisions.
TRANSCRIPT
+

About Lara Adler
Lara Adler is an Environmental Health Educator and Science Communicator with over 14 years of experience helping health professionals and health-focused businesses understand the impact of environmental chemicals on chronic health conditions. Her work bridges established and emerging research with practical, accessible strategies to minimize toxic exposures and build resilience against environmental challenges.
Combining environmental health education with business consulting, she has helped over 5,000 health professionals in more than 35 countries elevate their expertise, achieve better client outcomes, and become sought-after leaders in the growing field of environmental health.

title: Microplastics in Ovarian Follicular Fluid: What the Research Means for Fertility | Ep. 585
main_text:
Podcast Host
Lisa Hendrickson‑Jack is a Certified Fertility Awareness Educator and the author of The Fifth Vital Sign and Real Food for Fertility. She created the Fertility Awareness Mastery Mentorship (FAMM) to train practitioners to use the menstrual cycle as a vital sign in clinical care.
Audio Player
00:00
00:00
Use Up/Down Arrow keys to increase or decrease volume.
Podcast: Play in new window | Download | Embed
Subscribe: Apple Podcasts | RSS
Episode Overview
In Episode 585 of the Fertility Friday Podcast, Lisa Hendrickson-Jack breaks down a newly published and first-of-its-kind study identifying microplastics in human ovarian follicular fluid. This episode explores what microplastics are, how they enter the body, and why their presence in the fluid surrounding developing eggs raises important questions about female fertility.
Lisa walks listeners through the study design, its limitations, and what animal research suggests about the potential reproductive effects of microplastics. She also places the findings within the broader context of environmental toxin exposure, highlighting practical steps women and practitioners can take to reduce exposure while acknowledging the limits of individual control in a highly industrialized world.
Key Topics Covered
What microplastics are and how humans are exposed
The first evidence of microplastics in ovarian follicular fluid
Why follicular fluid is critical to egg development and quality
Study design, findings, and limitations
Animal research on microplastics and reproductive harm
Hormonal disruption, oxidative stress, and DNA damage
Connections between toxins, fertility, and menstrual health
Practical strategies to reduce microplastic exposure
Listener Takeaways
Microplastics are now confirmed in human ovarian follicular fluid.
Follicular fluid directly influences egg maturation and quality.
Animal studies show negative effects on hormones, eggs, sperm, and embryos.
Oxidative stress and inflammation are key mechanisms of harm.
Human fertility impacts are not yet fully understood.
Reducing exposure matters even when perfection isn’t possible.
Awareness and gradual changes can significantly lower toxin burden.
Key Moments (Timestamps & Detailed Summaries)
Episode Introduction & Study Overview ( 00:00 – 03:00 )
Lisa introduces the episode and explains why this newly published study is significant. She highlights that this is the first research to detect microplastics in human ovarian follicular fluid and explains why this finding warrants serious attention.
What Are Microplastics? ( 03:00 – 06:30 )
Lisa defines microplastics, explaining their size, how they form from plastic degradation, and the most common exposure routes, including food, water, air, and personal care products.
Study Design & Participant Details ( 06:30 – 10:30 )
Lisa breaks down the study methodology, explaining how follicular fluid from 18 IVF patients was analyzed. She highlights the key finding that microplastics were detected in 14 of the 18 samples.
Why Follicular Fluid Matters for Fertility ( 10:30 – 13:30 )
The episode explains the role of ovarian follicles and follicular fluid in egg development and maturation, connecting these findings to broader research on how environmental exposures influence egg quality.
Can This Study Prove Fertility Harm? ( 13:30 – 16:00 )
Lisa clarifies the study’s limitations, including the small sample size and lack of comparison groups, explaining why the research cannot yet establish a causal link between microplastics and infertility in humans.
What Animal Studies Reveal About Reproduction ( 16:00 – 18:30 )
Lisa reviews animal studies cited in the research, highlighting findings related to impaired sperm parameters, hormonal disruption, reduced egg quality, and altered embryo development.
Human Implications & Emerging Questions ( 18:30 – 20:30 )
Lisa reflects on what the detection of microplastics in reproductive fluid could mean for human fertility and why this discovery raises urgent questions for future research.
Reducing Exposure: Practical Strategies ( 20:30 – 22:00 )
The episode shifts to actionable steps listeners can take to reduce microplastic exposure, including minimizing plastic food storage, avoiding plastic bottles, reducing household dust, and prioritizing whole foods.
Final Thoughts & What’s Next ( 22:00 – 23:00 )
Lisa emphasizes awareness over perfection, reminding listeners that microplastics are widespread and total avoidance is unrealistic. She closes by previewing the upcoming interview with toxin expert Laura Adler.
TRANSCRIPT
+

title: Is PMS Disrupting Your Sleep? | FAMM Research Series | Ep. 584
main_text:
Podcast Host:
Lisa Hendrickson-Jack is a Certified Fertility Awareness Educator and the author of The Fifth Vital Sign and Real Food for Fertility. She created the Fertility Awareness Mastery Mentorship (FAMM) to train practitioners to use the menstrual cycle as a vital sign in clinical care.
Audio Player
00:00
00:00
Use Up/Down Arrow keys to increase or decrease volume.
Podcast: Play in new window | Download | Embed
Subscribe: Apple Podcasts | RSS
Episode Overview:
In Episode 584 of the Fertility Friday Podcast, Lisa Hendrickson-Jack examines the relationship between sleep disturbances and the menstrual cycle through the lens of recent research. The episode focuses on a study that explored sleep patterns in the days leading up to menstruation and during early menses, analyzing both subjective sleep reports and objective sleep-tracking data. Lisa offers a critical review of the study design, highlights gaps in hormone assessment, and challenges common assumptions about progesterone, PMS, and sleep disruption.
Key Topics Covered:
The connection between sleep disturbances and the perimenstrual phase
Overview and critique of the study “The Interaction of Sleep and Emotion Across the Menstrual Cycle.”
Differences between subjective sleep reports and objective sleep-tracking data
Mood changes associated with disrupted sleep around menstruation
Common research assumptions about progesterone, estrogen, and sleep
Limitations of menstrual cycle research that do not accurately confirm ovulation or hormone patterns
The importance of viewing the menstrual cycle as a vital sign rather than an inherent problem
Listener Takeaways:
Sleep disturbances tend to increase in the days leading up to menstruation and early menses, but the experience may feel worse than objective data suggests.
Research often oversimplifies the role of hormones, particularly progesterone, without measuring them accurately.
Correlation between hormonal changes and symptoms does not automatically indicate causation.
PMS and sleep issues are not universal and may reflect hormonal imbalance rather than normal female physiology.
More precise cycle tracking and hormone monitoring are essential for meaningful menstrual health research.
Key Moments (Timestamps & Detailed Summaries)
Introduction and Study Overview ( 00:00 – 04:00 )
Lisa introduces the episode’s focus on sleep disturbances across the menstrual cycle. She explains why sleep quality is an important but often misunderstood topic in women’s health research and previews her critical analysis of the study’s conclusions.
Study Design and Cycle Phase Identification ( 04:00 – 08:00 )
Lisa breaks down how researchers identified menstrual cycle phases using self-reported bleeding and LH testing. She explains why accurate ovulation confirmation and hormone measurement are essential when interpreting cycle-based findings.
Sleep Tracking Methods and Key Findings ( 08:00 – 13:00 )
The episode explores how sleep was assessed using wrist-worn devices and sleep diaries. Lisa compares subjective reports of disrupted sleep with objective sleep data, highlighting why perceived wakefulness was significantly higher during certain cycle phases.
Mood Changes and the Emotional Impact of Poor Sleep ( 13:00 – 18:00 )
Lisa reviews findings related to mood changes, including increased irritability and frustration during the perimenstrual phase. She connects disrupted sleep to emotional well-being while cautioning against oversimplified hormonal explanations.
Critiquing Progesterone and PMS Assumptions ( 18:00 – 23:00 )
Lisa challenges the assumption that progesterone inherently disrupts sleep due to increased body temperature. She explains normal luteal phase physiology and argues that hormone imbalance—not healthy progesterone function—is the more likely contributor to sleep issues.
Research Limitations and Future Directions ( 23:00 – 33:00 )
The episode concludes with a broader discussion on the limitations of menstrual cycle research. Lisa emphasizes the need for better hormone tracking, individualized analysis, and a shift away from framing women’s biology as inherently flawed or problematic.
TRANSCRIPT
+

title: Birth Trauma, Advocacy, and Empowered Birth Experiences with Hihi Stewart | Ep. 583
main_text:
Podcast Host:
Lisa Hendrickson-Jack is a Certified Fertility Awareness Educator and the author of The Fifth Vital Sign and Real Food for Fertility. She created the Fertility Awareness Mastery Mentorship (FAMM) to train practitioners to use the menstrual cycle as a vital sign in clinical care.
Audio Player
00:00
00:00
Use Up/Down Arrow keys to increase or decrease volume.
Podcast: Play in new window | Download | Embed
Subscribe: Apple Podcasts | RSS
Episode Overview:
In Episode 583 of the Fertility Friday Podcast, Lisa Hendrickson-Jack is joined by birth educator, advocate, and founder of The Birth Lounge, Hihi Stewart, for a deep and honest conversation about birth experiences, birth trauma, and the role of education, autonomy, and advocacy in shaping how women experience childbirth.
This episode explores why so many women feel disempowered during birth, how medical systems and cultural norms contribute to trauma, and what expectant parents can do to prepare for birth in a way that supports safety, flexibility, and informed decision-making. Lisa and Hihi discuss hospital versus home birth dynamics, the importance of aligned providers, and how preparation before labor can significantly impact postpartum healing and emotional well-being.
Key Topics Covered:
Birth trauma and how it develops
Avoidable vs. unavoidable birth trauma
Hospital birth culture and systemic barriers
Medical racism and the historical roots of obstetric care
The role of education and informed consent
Advocacy, autonomy, and patient rights in labor
Midwifery care vs. obstetrical models
Flexibility and realistic expectations for birth
The role of doulas and support teams
Preparing for birth without fear or rigidity
Listener Takeaways:
Birth trauma is often rooted in a lack of consent, communication, and respect
Education before birth significantly improves outcomes and confidence
Flexibility reduces emotional distress when birth doesn’t go as planned
Hospital policies are not laws, and patients retain bodily autonomy
Aligned providers and advocacy support are critical
Preparation supports both physical birth outcomes and emotional healing
Every woman deserves a birth experience rooted in dignity and respect
Key Moments (Timestamps & Detailed Summaries)
Episode Introduction & Framing the Conversation ( 00:00 – 08:00 )
Lisa introduces the episode’s focus on birth experiences and trauma. She explains why education, preparation, and advocacy matter, especially for first-time mothers navigating complex medical systems.
Meet Hihi Stewart & Her Background ( 08:00 – 16:00 )
Hihi shares her background in human development, early childhood education, and family systems. She explains how gaps in pre-birth education inspired her work supporting parents before labor begins.
Why Birth Feels So Hard for Many Women ( 16:00 – 26:00 )
The conversation explores cultural shifts, the loss of community support, childcare pressures, and how systemic structures contribute to fear, disempowerment, and overwhelm during birth.
Medical Racism & Historical Roots of Obstetric Care ( 26:00 – 36:00 )
Hihi discusses the origins of gynecological care, medical racism, and how historical mistreatment of women—particularly Black women—continues to shape modern birth practices.
Defining Birth Trauma ( 36:00 – 46:00 )
Birth trauma is broken down into unavoidable trauma (such as loss or rare medical emergencies) and avoidable trauma caused by coercion, lack of consent, or dismissive care.
Consent, Communication & Avoidable Trauma ( 46:00 – 56:00 )
Hihi shares examples of how trauma occurs when procedures are done without consent, pain is dismissed, or fear-based language is used. Clear communication is highlighted as a trauma-reducing tool.
Hospital vs. Midwifery Models & Autonomy ( 56:00 – 1:07:00 )
Lisa and Hihi compare obstetrical and midwifery models of care, discussing how trust is placed either in systems or in birthing individuals. The role of flexibility, preparation, and provider alignment is emphasized.
TRANSCRIPT
+
