title: Infertility and Endometriosis | Is Surgery The Answer? | Dr. Naomi Whittaker, MD | Ep. 582
main_text:
Podcast Host:
Lisa Hendrickson-Jack is a certified fertility awareness educator and holistic reproductive health practitioner with over 20 years of experience. As the host of the Fertility Friday Podcast and author of The Fifth Vital Sign, Lisa helps women understand their cycles, hormones, and reproductive health so they can make informed decisions.
Audio Player
00:00
00:00
Use Up/Down Arrow keys to increase or decrease volume.
Podcast: Play in new window | Download | Embed
Subscribe: Apple Podcasts | RSS
Episode Overview:
In Episode 582 of the Fertility Friday Podcast, Lisa Hendrickson-Jack interviews Dr. Naomi Whitaker, a board-certified OBGYN fertility surgeon specializing in restorative reproductive medicine, NaProTechnology, and the Creighton Model FertilityCare System. This in-depth conversation explores why so many women struggle to receive accurate diagnoses, effective treatment, and insurance coverage for gynecologic conditions such as endometriosis, PCOS, and unexplained infertility.

Dr. Whitaker explains how conventional women’s healthcare is largely built around symptom suppression, organ removal, and pharmaceutical interventions rather than restoring normal physiology. Together, Lisa and Dr. Whitaker unpack the systemic barriers within medical education, insurance reimbursement, and research design that limit access to restorative care. The episode highlights how cycle charting, fertility awareness, and targeted surgery can dramatically improve health outcomes, fertility potential, and quality of life—often rivaling or outperforming IVF when underlying issues are properly treated.
Key Topics Covered:
Restorative reproductive medicine and NaProTechnology
The Creighton Model FertilityCare System
Why is ovulation misunderstood in conventional medicine?
Medical training gaps around the menstrual cycle
Insurance barriers and poor reimbursement for women’s surgeries
Endometriosis myths, diagnosis, and excision surgery
Why is hysterectomy often promoted despite poor outcomes?
Infertility as a symptom of an underlying disease
Comparing IVF, IUI, and restorative treatment outcomes
Male factor fertility and overlooked diagnostic opportunities
Empowerment, advocacy, and cycle charting as a foundation of care
Listener Takeaways:
The menstrual cycle is a vital sign that offers critical diagnostic insight
Ovulation is a marker of health, not a problem to suppress
Endometriosis is a surgical disease that requires proper excision
Insurance structures often penalize high-quality women’s care
Restorative surgery can improve pain, fertility, and quality of life
IVF success rates are often overestimated and poorly contextualized
Male fertility is frequently ignored despite clear diagnostic signals
Cycle charting empowers women to advocate for better care
True informed consent requires understanding all available options
Key Moments (Timestamps & Detailed Summaries)
Episode Introduction & Guest Background ( 00:00 – 05:30 )
Lisa introduces Dr. Naomi Whitaker and frames the episode around frustrations many women experience with conventional medicine, fertility treatment, and surgical care access.
Dr. Whitaker’s Path into Restorative Medicine ( 05:30 – 12:00 )
Dr. Whitaker shares her personal journey into medicine, how cycle charting changed her perspective during medical school, and why NaProTechnology reshaped her career.
What Medical School Teaches About Women’s Health ( 12:00 – 18:00 )
The discussion reveals how ovulation is often framed as a risk rather than a vital function, and how suppression becomes the default approach in standard medical training.
What Is Restorative Reproductive Medicine? ( 18:00 – 25:00 )
Dr. Whitaker explains NaProTechnology, the Creighton Model, and how fertility awareness biomarkers guide targeted testing and treatment.
Using the Menstrual Cycle as a Diagnostic Tool ( 25:00 – 33:00 )
Lisa and Dr. Whitaker discuss how cycle charts reveal inflammation, hormonal imbalance, PCOS, luteal phase defects, and early signs of endometriosis.
Insurance, Surgery, and Systemic Barriers ( 33:00 – 40:00 )
Dr. Whitaker explains how women’s surgeries—especially endometriosis excision—are poorly reimbursed, forcing many skilled surgeons into cash-pay models.
Endometriosis Myths & Mismanagement ( 40:00 – 46:00 )
The conversation addresses common myths, including hysterectomy as treatment, pain as the only symptom, and the false idea of “asymptomatic” endometriosis.
Infertility, IVF, and Alternative Outcomes ( 46:00 – 50:00 )
Dr. Whitaker challenges assumptions about IVF success rates, discusses selective tubal procedures, and explains why treating root causes often yields better outcomes.
Advocacy, Empowerment & Final Thoughts ( 50:00 – 53:00 )
The episode concludes with practical guidance on cycle charting, self-education, finding curious providers, and building grassroots advocacy for better women’s healthcare.
TRANSCRIPT
+

Could cycle charting hold the key to solving gut issues, fertility struggles, and uncovering hidden diagnoses—without expensive lab tests? Tune into my latest interview with Lauren as she shares her menstrual journey.
Lauren Mallers is a Certified Integrative Health Practitioner and founder of Calibrate Health & Wellness, where she helps women get to the root of chronic symptoms and hormone imbalances—without the bandaid fixes. After a 15-year career in digital media and a personal journey through IBS, fertility struggles, postpartum depletion, and hormone chaos, Lauren took her passion for data and turned it inward—using functional lab testing, nutrition, and lifestyle medicine to reclaim her health. Now, she helps other women do the same.
Her work focuses on identifying the real reasons behind fatigue, fertility struggles, gut issues, and hormonal symptoms using a personalized, data-driven approach. When she’s not coaching clients or interpreting test results, you’ll find her chasing her two kids, cooking something protein-heavy, or at a yoga class.

What if your “healthy habits” are shutting down your menstrual cycle? In this episode with Dr. Ashley Burton, we unpack how fasting, overtraining, and stress can lead to period loss—and how cycle charting can guide the way back to ovulation and hormonal health.
Dr. Ashley Burton is a chiropractor and holistic nutritionist specializing in fertility nutrition coaching and bringing awareness to the menstrual cycle as a key indicator of overall health. She holds a Bachelor of Science in Biomedical Sciences from the University of Guelph, a Doctor of Chiropractic degree from the Canadian Memorial Chiropractic College in Toronto, Ontario, and a Diploma in Natural Nutrition from the Canadian School of Natural Nutrition.
With a background in personal training since 2012 and a specialization in pre- and postnatal exercise science, Ashley has dedicated her career to supporting women’s health. As a chiropractor, she focuses on prenatal and postpartum care, with a strong emphasis on core and pelvic floor rehabilitation, as well as general family care.
Ashley’s approach is evidence-based and holistic, recognizing the deep mind-body connection in healing. She understands firsthand the challenges of hormonal health, having struggled with long and missing cycles due to overexercise and undernutrition. Through her work, she helps individuals optimize their health, fertility, and overall well-being by integrating movement, nutrition, and education.
Based on Vancouver Island, Ashley is passionate about empowering people with the tools to support their bodies naturally—whether through chiropractic care, fertility-focused nutrition, or lifestyle adjustments.

Could the menstrual cycle be the missing piece in understanding and treating psychiatric disorders, especially PMDD? Tune in as we break down a recent study calling for the inclusion of menstrual cycle awareness in psychiatric care.
Today’s episode is sponsored by FAMM, the Fertility Awareness Mastery Mentorship program! Follow this link to join the waiting list for our next class (July 2025)!

Topics discussed in today’s episode:
How PMDD severely impacts daily life, while PMS typically doesn’t.
Why women with PMDD experience significant dips in progesterone relative to estrogen during the luteal phase.
How treating hormone imbalances through diet, lifestyle, and supplementation can significantly reduce PMDD symptoms, potentially lessening the need for psychiatric medications.
How recognizing the menstrual cycle as a vital sign could greatly improve psychiatric care for women.
How one authors experience with a psychiatric diagnosis seemed to coincide with her menstrual cycle.
Why there are more studies focused specifically on women’s cycles, as most research has historically focused on men, ignoring the unique factors women face.

Red light therapy isn’t just a wellness trend—it’s a fertility tool with serious science behind it. From powering up your mitochondria to improving egg and sperm quality, this episode will change the way you think about light and conception.
Tracy Donegan, MSc, CLT is a midwife, author, and certified light therapist dedicated to advancing reproductive health through photobiomodulation (PBM) therapy. As the founder of Solasta in Round Rock Texas, she provides evidence-based laser and red light treatments to support fertility, optimize mitochondrial health, and enhance overall well-being in women’s health. With a background in midwifery, Tracy integrates scientific research with holistic care, offering innovative approaches to reproductive wellness.  Tracy’s blog provides comprehensive evidence based information on PBMT for women’s health.
With a MSc in Mindfulness Tracy is also the creator of the FertileMind app, an international speaker, and a passionate advocate for the intersection of light, circadian biology, and fertility. Through her work, Tracy supports women and their partners with science-backed tools to navigate fertility challenges, PCOS, endometriosis, and IVF support.

How common are cycle changes as you approach menopause? Today I break down a fascinating study that measured cycle changes during the 10 years before menopause so you know what to expect.
Today’s episode is sponsored by FAMM, the Fertility Awareness Mastery Mentorship program! Follow this link to join the waiting list for our next class (July 2025)!
Today’s episode is also sponsored by Lisa’s newest book Real Food for Fertility, co-authored with Lily Nichols. Click here to grab your copy today!

00:00
00:00
Use Up/Down Arrow keys to increase or decrease volume.
Podcast: Play in new window | Download | Embed
Subscribe: Apple Podcasts | RSS
Topics discussed in today’s episode:
Understanding how cycle changes in perimenopause were originally studied and why reanalyzing the data gives us a clearer picture of this transition.
What typical cycle changes look like in the years leading up to menopause, including shortening of cycle length and increasing cycle irregularity.
How the cycle doesn’t dramatically fluctuate until the last few years before menopause, especially in the two years leading up to the final period.
Why we need to stop viewing menopause as a singular event and embrace the entire transition period, including perimenopause, as a natural and healthy process.
Why tracking your cycle in perimenopause can help you understand your body better and know when changes are outside the typical range.

title: FFP 568 | Barriers To Fertility Awareness Research | New Research on Miscarriage | Dr. Marguerite Duane, MD
main_text:
Audio Player
00:00
00:00
Use Up/Down Arrow keys to increase or decrease volume.
Podcast: Play in new window | Download | Embed
Subscribe: Apple Podcasts | RSS
Have you ever wondered why fertility awareness research doesn’t get the attention it deserves? Or why miscarriage remains such a silent and misunderstood issue? Dr. Marguerite Duane joins me to discuss the challenges of publishing fertility research, the real reasons behind miscarriage, and how we can change the landscape for women’s health.
Dr. Marguerite Duane, a board-certified family physician, is co-founder and Executive Director of FACTS about Fertility, an organization dedicated to educating medical professionals and students about the scientific evidence supporting fertility awareness-based methods (FABMs). She also serves as an Adjunct Associate Professor at Georgetown and Duquesne University, where she is the Director of the Center of Fertility Awareness Education and Research. Dr. Duane cares for patients via her own direct primary care house-calls based practice, MD for Life, in the Washington, DC area.
Dr. Duane trained as a Creighton, FEMM and NeoFertility Medical consultant, and a TeenSTAR educator. She received her M.D. degree from the State University of New York at Stony Brook and completed her Family Medicine residency at Lancaster General Hospital in Pennsylvania. She received a Bachelor of Science with Honors and a Master of Health Administration degree from Cornell University. In 2022, Dr. Duane completed a primary care research fellowship at the University of Utah earning a Master of Science in Public Health. Dr. Duane is married to fellow family physician, Dr. Kenneth Lin, and they are delighted to be the parents of 4 children.
Today’s episode is sponsored by FAMM, the Fertility Awareness Mastery Mentorship program! Follow this link to join the waiting list for our next class (July 2025)!
Today’s episode is also sponsored by Lisa’s newest book Real Food for Fertility, co-authored with Lily Nichols. Click here to grab your copy today!

Topics discussed in today’s episode:
Dr. Duane reveals the challenges behind getting fertility awareness research published, including the financial and institutional barriers that often prevent critical studies from reaching the public.
How miscarriage is one of the most common yet least discussed health issues, and why it’s important to understand its true impact.
How low progesterone, low estradiol, and thyroid imbalances can increase the risk of miscarriage, and how addressing these issues may reduce the risk of pregnancy loss.
Advice on how women who have experienced miscarriage and feel their concerns are being dismissed by healthcare providers can advocate for themselves
Dr. Duane’s efforts through FACTS to train medical professionals about fertility awareness and its importance in reproductive health.

The white lies about the pill are crashing down around us! In today’s episode I decimate a recent research article trying desperately to invalidate women’s concerns about hormonal birth control.
Today’s episode is sponsored by FAMM, the Fertility Awareness Mastery Mentorship program! Follow this link to join the waiting list for our next class (July 2025)!
Today’s episode is also sponsored by Lisa’s newest book Real Food for Fertility, co-authored with Lily Nichols. Click here to grab your copy today!

Topics discussed in today’s episode:
A look at the financial influence on promoting hormonal birth control and why there’s resistance to discussing its side effects openly.
Common physical and mental side effects associated with hormonal birth control and why it’s important to acknowledge the reality of these effects instead of brushing them off.
The impact of hormonal contraception on mood and mental health.
Whether hormonal birth control impacts long-term fertility and if there temporary subfertility after discontinuing the pill.
The effect of hormonal contraception on sexual function and desire.
How hormonal birth control has been linked to both increased risks (cervical and breast cancer) and decreased risks (ovarian and endometrial cancer).

From 3 years without a period to consistent, healthy cycles! Tune into my latest interview to learn more about how Grace plans to inspire other women to do the same.  
Grace Parce is a certified integrative nutritionist and fertility awareness educator dedicated to helping women find real solutions to hormonal imbalances often dismissed or normalized by conventional medicine. Through her business, OvaFreak, Grace empowers women to gain body literacy, improve their menstrual health, and take control of their fertility. Her personal struggles with hormonal birth control, PMDD, and irregular cycles inspired her to seek solutions beyond mainstream approaches. Grace trained in nutrition at the Institute of Integrative Nutrition and in Fertility Awareness Methods

Rhoda’s Chee’s root cause, personalized support helps encourage and empower you to take control of your fertility and achieve your goals with research and data-backed information. Rhoda is a Registered Dietitian Nutritionist (RDN), ELNA Certified Fertility and Pregnancy Dietitian, and FAMM Certified Practitioner in training. Follow these steps to boost fertility and balance hormones! Lily Nichols joins me this week as we celebrate the 1-year anniversary of Real Food for Fertility! We share some of the most compelling success stories we’ve received from readers all over the world!
Lily Nichols is a Registered Dietitian/Nutritionist, Certified Diabetes Educator, researcher, and author with a passion for evidence-based nutrition. Her work is known for being research-focused, thorough, and sensible. She is the founder of the Institute for Prenatal Nutrition®, co-founder of the Women’s Health Nutrition Academy, and the author of three books: Real Food for Fertility (co-authored with Lisa Hendrickson-Jack), Real Food for Pregnancy, and Real Food for Gestational Diabetes. Lily’s bestselling books have helped tens of thousands of mamas (and babies!), are used in university-level maternal nutrition and midwifery courses, and have even influenced prenatal nutrition policy internationally. She writes at https://lilynicholsrdn.com. When she steps away from writing, you can find her spending time with her husband and two children — most likely outside or in the kitchen.

If you’ve wondered why so many medical providers are biased against fertility awareness we get into it in today’s episode with Emmy Poole!
Emmy is the woman behind She Is The Moon, a women’s wellness practice. She is a Maya Abdominal Practitioner and soon to be Fertility Awareness Educator. Emmy also works as a surgical technologist and gets the unique perspective of seeing the inner workings of the body, literally. This unique perspective has let her see things like adhesions, fibroids, misaligned uteruses, and so much more. It has made her even more passionate about Maya Abdominal Therapy and FAM, in hopes to help women seek other options before deciding to take the surgical route. It is Emmy’s goal to help educate women about their bodies, to teach them things we should have been taught, and help them claim back their bodily autonomy through education and reconnecting with their bodies.

In today’s episode Dr. Josephine Razon, DPT shares how she eliminated her menstrual migranes with our FAMM protocols!
Dr. Josephine Razon is a Doctor of Physical Therapy and a certified pelvic health specialist. She is also a Mercier Therapist and a FAMM-certified practitioner in training. 
With a holistic approach, she helps women by providing fertility support with manual therapy techniques and educating them about their menstrual cycles. She also works with women throughout their pregnancy and postpartum recovery to address issues like leaking, heaviness, pelvic pain, and returning them to back to activities symptom-free. 
Dr. Josephine has her bachelor’s degree in Kinesiology from the University of Nevada- Las Vegas and her Doctorate in Physical Therapy from The University of St. Augustine for Health Sciences. 
She is the owner of Evolve Pelvic PT and Wellness in Las Vegas, Nevada and provides mobile pelvic health physical therapy services.

Whether your hormone balance is off, you don’t have enough energy to get through the day,  or you can’t lose that excess weight optimizing your metabolism is essential to turning it around! Lara Briden joins me today to discuss her new book Metabolism Repair for Women.
Lara Briden is a naturopath and the bestselling author of the books Period Repair Manual, Hormone Repair Manual, and her newest book Metabolism Repair for Women — practical guides to treating period problems with nutrition, supplements, and body-identical hormones. A graduate of the Canadian College of Naturopathic Medicine (1997) and the University of Calgary (evolutionary biology), Lara serves on several scientific advisory committees, including The Centre for Ovulation and Menstruation Research (CeMCOR) at the University of British Columbia. She is a popular speaker and has delivered keynote presentations for the Endocrinology Association of Naturopathic Physicians (EndoANP), the Australasian Integrative Medicine Association (AIMA), the Australasian College of Nutritional and Environmental Medicine (ACNEM), and the University of Canterbury.
Lara has consulting rooms in Christchurch, New Zealand, where she treats women with PCOS, PMS, endometriosis, perimenopause, and many other hormone- and period-related health problems.

Find out how Michelle overcame her heavy and painful periods by implementing the FAMM process in today’s episode!
For nearly a decade Michelle worked in the tech industry at firms like Bazaarvoice, LinkedIn and Shopify. It made her wonder why she had never heard about working in sync with her cycle before! Fast forward to today, and Michelle teaches companies the benefits of incorporating cycle syncing in the workplace! She equips her clients with the confidence to come off hormonal birth control and address underlying symptoms so they can actually enjoy their periods. Having lived in London, Munich, San Francisco and Sydney, Michelle brings a global perspective. She believes that all women deserve to learn body literacy so they can thrive.

She will teach you how to chart your menstrual cycle so that you can track your overall health, prevent pregnancy naturally, and/or optimize conception.

Why are so many couples choosing egg donation? At what point should it be considered? Find out in today’s episode with Marc Sklar!
Dr. Marc Sklar — a.k.a The Fertility Expert — is a natural fertility specialist helping couples get pregnant for 20 years. His mission is to help you feel hopeful and confident about your fertility journey again. 
In addition to his Doctor of Acupuncture and Oriental Medicine, Dr. Sklar trained at the Harvard Medical School, Mind/Body Medical Institute. He is the creator of Fertility TV, MarcSklar.com and ReproductiveWellness.com, and the co-author of Secret to Conception and a Fellow of the American Board of Oriental Reproductive Medicine and Medical Advisor for Natural Health International.
He also supports his community via his highly popular YouTube channel: FertilityTV where he shares information-packed videos to educate his followers on all things fertility. 
The Fertility Expert lives in San Diego, with his wife and two sons, where he has a clinic, Reproductive Wellness. He also works with couples all over the world (virtually) through his Hope Fertility Program online.

Discover the unexpected factors that impact fertility in my interview with Michelle Oravitz!
Michelle Oravitz, L.Ac, FABORM is an acupuncturist, specializing in Fertility Health. She found her love in Chinese medicine after it helped her through her own menstrual cycle challenges and this inspired her to change her career from architecture to acupuncture. 
Michelle is the host of a top-rated podcast called ‘The Wholesome Fertility Podcast’. She has been endorsed by best-selling authors such as Aimee Raupp, Jessica Ortner, and Dr. Lisa Miller. 
Michelle has been on a mission to help women get pregnant (naturally and via IVF preparation) through her one-on-one work at her acupuncture clinic and online. She recently authored a new book, The Way of Fertility, which dives deep into the energetics of fertility through the lens of ancient wisdom. Michelle believes that our bodies are hardwired to procreate and by connecting to our inherent wisdom, we can awaken our natural reproductive vitality.

I could have called today’s episode: “Listen to this before starting your IVF journey!” My guest Tasha shares her take on what IVF doctors get wrong in the IVF process, and what you should do instead.
Tasha Blasi is an IVF consultant and Founder of IVF Uncovered. Using her background in the sciences, and personally going through ten rounds of IVF for her two children, she has created a life mission to help patients doing IVF know almost as much as their doctor about perfect protocols and strategies so they can protect their investment plus increase their chances for success…all while bringing an unfiltered, humorous tone to this often heartbreaking subject.
Tasha offers group and private IVF consulting services and hosts the popular podcast, “IVF Uncovered.”  You can find her online at TashaBlasi.com.
